column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106808,2022,Capita aansprakelijkheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['mr. BV Rozema', 'mr. MR Hebly', 'prof.mr. KJO Jansen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Tijdens het vak Capita Aansprakelijkheidsrecht vergaart u kennis van diverse onderwerpen[1] op het gebied van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht. Bij dit vak wordt voornamelijk gebruik gemaakt van gastdocenten; specialisten op het gebied van de te behandelen onderwerpen. Naast de colleges, waarin een actieve werkvorm centraal staat, zijn er ook masterclasses. Tijdens deze masterclasses bezoekt u steeds een organisatie (advocatuur/verzekeringsbranche) waar een van de onderwerpen uit het vak wordt uitgediept waardoor direct de uitwerking daarvan in de praktijk zichtbaar is. [1] De belangrijkste capita zijn structuur van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht, verjarings- en vervaltermijnen, beroepsaansprakelijkheid, werkgeversaansprakelijkheid, verkeersaansprakelijkheid, productaansprakelijkheid en overheidsaansprakelijkheid.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren en uiteen zetten.
• U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
• U kunt ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
• U kunt op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
• U kunt verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
• U kunt de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en u kunt daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder volgt een korte beschrijving van de Capita Selecta Transfer Pricing:

Tijdens de colleges staat het Transfer Pricing vakgebied centraal. Zo zullen wij tijdens de colleges uitgebreid stil staan bij de internationaalrechtelijke aspecten van Transfer Pricing, alsmede de Nederlandse implementatie van de Transfer Pricing regels, inclusief bijbehorende jurisprudentie. De Transfer Pricing discipline is volop in beweging. Tijdens de colleges zullen daarom ook de recente ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de Transfer Pricing aan bod komen.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor een nadere omschrijving wordt verwezen naar de brochures die per Capita Selecta beschikbaar zijn op Canvas.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Caribisch fiscaal recht:

Tijdens de colleges wordt ingegaan op het fiscale stelsel van de BES eilanden (Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba) en ACS (Aruba, Curaçao en Sint Maarten). Aan de orde komen de staatkundige vernieuwing van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden, de directe en indirecte belastingen, formeel belastingrecht, belastingrechtspraak in het Caribisch gebied, tax incentives (tax holiday, e-zone), internationale aspecten (verdragen, BRN, BRK, verhouding met EU), misbruik van offshore vennootschappen (Panama leaks, 'Ultimate Beneficial Owner'), tax haven en ethiek. Daarnaast wordt een uitstap gemaakt naar het fiscale stelsel van Suriname.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken.

Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de Caput Formeel Belastingrecht:

Tijdens de colleges worden relevante formeelrechtelijke onderwerpen belicht vanuit de praktijk, waarbij in de in de loop van de studie de behandelde onderdelen geïntegreerd worden bestudeerd. column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in zes specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Van eenmanszaak tot internationaal concern:

De cyclus van 16 colleges wordt begonnen met verschillende aspecten die van belang zijn voor familievennootschappen. Daarbij gaat het om zowel civielrechtelijke als fiscaalrechtelijke aspecten. Onderwerpen die daarbij aan de orde komen zijn: ondernemingsfaciliteiten, bedrijfsopvolging in de inkomstenbelasting en vennootschapsbelasting, de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteit voor de schenk- en erfbelasting, het creëren van holdingstructuren, horizontaal toezicht en tax assurance, ethiek en renteaftrekbeperkingen.

Met betrekking tot het internationale deel van deze capita zullen de volgende onderwerpen behandeld worden: transfer pricing, classificatie van hybride entiteiten, doorstromers, immigratie en emigratie aanmerkelijkbelanghouder en vennootschap, verdragsonderhandelingen, BEPS/ATAD en belastingheffing in de digitale economie en fiscale aspecten van grensoverschrijdende werknemers en hybride entiteiten. De focus bij deze onderwerpen ligt op het internationale concern.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor nadere informatie wordt verwezen naar de brochures die voor deze Capita Selecta beschikbaar is op canvas.</body>

column1: <body>Het verzekeringsrecht staat niet op zichzelf. Er wordt altijd ""iets"" verzekerd en dat ""iets"" kan met vele juridische deelgebieden verweven zijn. Verzekering vervult in onze moderne samenleving met alle daaraan verbonden kansen en risico's ook een onmisbare rol in het veiligstellen van de sociale zekerheid voor het individu. Dat maakt het verzekeringsrecht tot een boeiend onderdeel van het recht. Het betekent ook dat kennis van het verzekeringsrecht niet alleen onmisbaar is voor juristen die in de verzekeringsbranche zelf werkzaam (willen) zijn of bijvoorbeeld in de advocatuur de belangen van verzekeraars vertegenwoordigen. In feite loopt iedereen die in een juridische functie (rechterlijke macht, bedrijfsleven, overheid) werkzaam is, de kans met verzekeringsrechtelijke vraagstukken te worden geconfronteerd; zoals dat ook privé het geval is.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of cluster 4. The Politics of Wealth: Inequality, Capitalism, Exploitation

This course covers state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, including the debate on permissible commodification and the nature of markets, on contemporary justifications of property, on the feminist and the three-dimensional theory of power, on justice as fairness and its approach to economic inequality, on neo-republicanism, and on contemporary theories of exploitation.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To provide students with advanced knowledge of contemporary political philosophy. By the end of the course, students should have an understanding of state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, the ability to think well about them, and the ability to assess relevant philosophical theories in terms of their cogency and explanatory scope.
Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106411,2022,Capitalism and Inequality,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. DR Curtis', 'R van Lent, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Crises such as the 2008/9 financial crash and COVID-19 have thrown a window on one of the world’s greatest issues – inequality. In this course, we place the emergence of capitalism and the growth of inequality in a long-term historical perspective. How did we get here? As with most of our pernicious contemporary challenges, much has its roots in developments going back far into the past. Over these 8 sessions, it’s our job to unravel them. Has history been one relentless march towards greater inequality, or have there been periods in which we have become more egalitarian? Is it possible to prevent inequality? Furthermore, what do we mean when say “inequality” – and how does that definition apply in specific historical contexts? Is something unequal if the society in question does not observe it to be unequal? A major aspect of this course is understanding some of the mechanisms that have led societies towards inegalitarian outcomes. What is the relationship between capitalism and inequality, or colonialism and inequality? What do we mean by “extractive societies”? How have hazards, shocks and disasters affected inequality, and vice-versa, how has inequality affected societies’ resilience, vulnerability and coping strategies in the face of hazards, shocks and disasters? And finally, how has economic inequality intersected with other issues regarding gender, race and sexuality, in order to forge new kinds of marginalization?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can reflect upon the relative and fluid nature of the term “inequality” – recognizing it can mean something different depending on historical context.
• Students can plot the geographical and temporal dimensions of inequality over time for different parts of the world.
• Students can explain why certain historical societies have become more unequal in certain periods of time.
• Students can identify some of the consequences of economic inequality – especially in its interaction with other concepts such as resilience and vulnerability.

column1: The Capstone project is the accumulation of what you have learned during your liberal arts and science education at EUC. As such, the Capstone project is considered to be a 400-level course. The Capstone is an individual project that should be seen as an 'aptitude test'. As a Bachelor in Science, you should be able to formulate and answer a research question or defend a claim related to your Major in a scientific way. This ability may be proven in different ways, depending on your Major. Your results will have to be collected, analysed and discussed in an academic way in the final product of your Capstone, your Capstone thesis.
The aim of the Capstone is that you learn to:

- recognise an academically relevant problem, define a research question or claim, and perform scientific research. During this research, you will learn how to collect, interpret, and analyse relevant information from academic sources and/or scientific data. You will gain the ability to distinguish between facts and opinions, and between main and side issues;
- understand, analyse, and critically evaluate academic texts; - have a critical and reflective attitude that contributes to collecting, interpreting, and analysing the relevant sources;
- present the outcomes of your Capstone thesis.</body>

column1: Belangrijk: Dit online vak is een verplicht onderdeel van het Career Skills programma.
Het doel van Your Future Career is studenten voor te bereiden op hun carrière.

Als je geeft om wat je doet, zal je met meer plezier werken, meer impact creëren, en succesvoller zijn. Het kan echter lastig zijn om erachter te komen wat jouw passie is, waar je jouw competenties en vaardigheden het beste in kan zetten, en wat voor professionele werkomgeving en -cultuur het beste bij je past. Het Career Skills programma biedt dit online vak aan om je de leiding te geven over je eigen carrière en je te ondersteunen in het kiezen voor en voorbereiden op je eerste stap in je carrière.

De online modules van Your Future Career helpen je om cruciale stappen te maken richting de stage of baan die het best bij jou past. Om het vak succesvol af te sluiten dien je 28 punten te verdienen. Je kan zelf bepalen of je wil reflecteren op je interesses en motivaties, kennis op wil doen over de arbeidsmarkt, functies, organisaties en sectoren, of feedback van je medestudenten wilt ontvangen op je sollicitatie documenten.
Dit online vak begint in blok 3 en loopt tot eind blok 4. Je kunt niet halverwege met het vak starten.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het op waarde schatten van je eigen professionele profiel in de grotere gemeenschap
• Pro-actief zijn met betrekking tot het voorbereiden op je carrière
• Analyseer je sterke en zwakke punten, personaliteit, waardes, en vaardigheden
• Identificeer gaten in de voorbereiding op je carrière en creëer actiepunten om deze gaten te vullen
• Leer over het wervings- en selectieproces in verschillende sectoren
• Bepaal hoe jouw toekomstige carrière een kracht voor positieve verandering kan zijn
• Demonstreer geschreven en verbale communicatievaardigheden die nodig zijn in het sollicitatieproces
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Deze cursus is onderdeel van het Career Skills programma. Merk op dat, met uitzondering van de cursus FEB13901 (X) Your Future Career, alle cursussen beperkte plaatsen beschikbaar hebben. Studenten voor wie Career Skills verplicht is, hebben voorrang bij het abonneren op Career Skills-cursussen

Indien je in 2018-2019 of eerder met je bachelor begonnen bent, is Career Skills geen verplicht programma voor jou. Je kunt wel een van de cursussen uit dit programma volgen, bijvoorbeeld als je een extra credit nodig hebt om je bachelor af te ronden. Om te registreren voor een cursus stuur je een email naar careerskills@ese.eur.nl.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Are you a member of a field hockey club, a student association, or a political party? In any of these cases, and many more, you were probably asked to give back at some point. For example, by refereeing a junior game, tending the bar for a few nights, or campaigning for your party. Did you realise that at that point you were volunteering? The Netherlands is a true volunteer country, almost 50% of individuals older than 15 donates their time at least once a year as a volunteer. On average, these volunteers spend about 4 hours a week at their volunteer-job. That is about 700.000 FTE! Could you imagine how much more a field-hockey membership would cost if all these people would have to be paid? Free or low-cost services would have to be stopped or expensed in a different way and campaigning for political parties or foodbanks might be practically non-existent?

The value of volunteer hours, in essence unpaid labour, is exactly what we will focus on during this Career Skills Course. Students will explore how these non-profit organisations must be managed differently from their for-profit counterparts. You will then focus on the complex issue of how organisations can value their volunteers. In this interactive course you will work with current cases and learn how to evaluate the different stakeholders and the value of volunteers for a non-profit organisation of your choice. You will work on your critical thinking, case solving and pitching skills.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course the student is able to:
1. Describe the functioning and complexity of non-profit, non-governmental and philanthropic organisations and the civil society (third sector)
2. Apply theoretical civil society concepts to real-life situations
3. Evaluate the value of volunteers for a non-profit organisation of your choice
4. Analyze the differences between paid work and volunteering / for-profit and non-profit organisations
5. Advance a career in the third sector and in (impact) evaluation

column1: Find a shortened description below. For more information, check out the Career Skills Hub Canvas page.

You can find the courses offered in the Career Skills programme in the study guide. To do so, open the study guide, choose ‘Erasmus School of Economics’, then ‘Overige onderwijs’ or ‘Miscellaneous’, then ‘Career Skills’.

Being a student is not only about getting that diploma. Your time at Erasmus School of Economics is an excellent opportunity to gain hands-on experience and develop the skills you’ll need to start a successful professional career. Make the most of your studies, strengthen your employability and make yourself sought after by recruiters.

The Career Skills programme aims to foster a better connection between the study at ESE and the labour market. It is the wish of ESE to stimulate you to make informed choices regarding your studies and the start of your career. In addition, we want to support students in developing the skills necessary to succeed in a professional environment. That way, you will be well prepared to enter working life!
For whom is the Career Skills programme?

The Career Skills programme is obligatory for all ESE students who started their bachelor programme in academic year 2019-2020 or later. Students in Economics & Business Economics, Econometrics & Operations Research, and Fiscale Economie take the Career Skills programme in the third year of their bachelor. BSc2 students take with the programme in the fourth year of their bachelor.
All bachelor students do the online course Your Future Career (FEB13901) in block 3 and 4. In block 5 they can choose a second Career Skills course that suits their needs.

If you started your bachelor in 2018-2019 or earlier, Career Skills is not a mandatory programme for you. You can still follow one of the courses in this programme, for instance if you need one more credit to finish your bachelor. To register, send an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl.
What courses does the Career Skills programme offer?
In 2022/2023, you can choose between the following courses:

column2: • FAECTOR Case-solving and Assessment Training

column1: The course will be divided into 3 main themes: Public Speaking, Argumentation, Real-world debating skills. During the course, students will attend various lectures and workshops centered around these three themes, which build onto each other. Instructors in these lectures and workshops will consist of a variety of professors, professionals from companies and NGOs or experienced members of associations such as the Erasmus Debate Society. Throughout the course, students will be given assignments to prepare certain topics and arguments in order to be able to present them during the workshops. Hence, the lectures will serve as introductions to the topics and the related skills will be practiced during the corresponding workshops.

column1: 1. Speech construction: Students learn the basic formatting principles to a speech and simple argument structures.
2. Public speaking skills: Students will learn how to better present themselves and increase their confidence for public speaking.
3. Argumentation skills: Students will be able to create solid and sound detailed arguments
4. Negotiation skills: Students will understand how a negotiation process works with basic negotiation concepts and principles

During the Dutch language course for beginners you will learn the basics of the Dutch language, with emphasis on reading, speaking, listening and writing skills in an everyday context. You do not need to pass an intake interview.
The course consist of seven meetings of two hours. Next to this, the self-study and preparation time amount to circa 14 hours.

column1: Before the start of the course you are required to submit, via Canvas, a motivation letter why you want to participate. This letter will be used in-class.
Effective business communication in English opens doors. Excellent communication skills in English are crucial for achieving international ambitions.

In this course you will work on your Business English writing skills, for example by writing polite, concise and correct business emails. You will also get the opportunity to practice your presentation skills in English by giving a persuasive and informative business presentation. You will learn more about conventions in Business English in this course. You will brush up your English grammar and you will be able to improve and expand your English vocabulary. By receiving individual feedback from your lecturer – who is an experienced language professional – you will be able to develop your business communication skills. You will also learn a great deal from working closely together with your fellow students.
This course consists of seven plenary sessions of two hours. Next to this the self-study and preparation time amounts to circa 14 hours.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You can write a coherent and well-structured English business text
• You can write correct English on the sentence level, including grammar, style, and vocabulary
• You will develop an efficient writing process
• You can give a good business presentation in English

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship, we are committed to developing people’s entrepreneurial skills because we believe these skills to be crucial for young people’s ability to successfully choose and shape their own career and life paths. Broader than the skills needed to establish and grow a company, an entrepreneurial mindset leads to more resilient individuals, that are better able to spot and strategically act upon opportunities.
During this course offered by Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship, you will work on developing the competencies needed to shape your career in an solution-oriented and impactful way.

The course consists of five modules, each highlighting a different ‘area’ of entrepreneurship. The three main pillars along which the modules are structured are the entrepreneurship process in a startup, in a scaleup environment and in a corporate/public environment. You will practice with and reflect on this process throughout the course and apply it in the final module which will be a mini-innovation challenge.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Have developed an understanding of main entrepreneurial principles such as design thinking, lean startup and effectuation;
• Know how to apply the theory of effectuation and effectuation roadmap to concretise a vision or way to make impact that you identified during the course;
• Know how to apply entrepreneurial principles to identify and empathise with a target group for whom you want to realise your vision/impact;
• Are able to pitch yourself or your solution to a problem in front of different audiences including your (future) employer;
• Are able to ideate and come up with solutions to social/societal challenges pressure-cooker style.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: FAECTOR Case-Solving and Assessment Training is part of the Career Skills programme of the ESE. This course is organised by FAECTOR, the official study association for students studying Econometrie, Econometrics, and the Bsc2 Econometrics/Economics programme.

During the course, students will work on three real-life cases from participating companies. These participating companies will conduct a considerable part of their business operations within econometrics and employ a significant number of people with a quantitative or econometric-related background. Throughout the course, students will be given assignments to prepare the cases and evaluate the results. In addition, assessment training will be provided to get acquainted with company assessments and to increase your mathematical and analytical skills.

Through active participation and solving cases, students will develop practical skills that will increase their opportunities in the job market by showing them what to expect from the application procedure and giving them the skills necessary to pass parts of that procedure. Not only will you gain a potential advantage during your job applications, but you might meet your future employer.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Better understanding of the (quantitative) job market in general
• Better understanding of application procedures, knowledge of what to expect besides the traditional CV, motivation letter and interview rounds.
• Practical experience with passing assessments and solving case studies as part of the application process
• Improved knowledge of the tools necessary to pass assessments and cases
• Practical experience with quickly processing a lot of information in order to reach a conclusion about a problem at hand
• Increased knowledge of the career opportunities within the field of econometrics

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: FSR Professional Skills in Finance is a Career Skills course for ESE students who want to expand their knowledge and skills required for a successful career in the increasingly competitive world of Finance. Pursuing a career in Finance is an excellent choice for students who want to understand how the world economy functions and what the secrets are behind money, investments, and financial independence.

The course FSR Professional Skills in Finance will be based on four big pillars in the world of Finance: (i) Mergers & Acquisitions, (ii) Consultancy, (iii) Asset Management, and (iv) Accounting. These four pillars serve as the overarching topics that will be addressed in this Career Skills course. So, if you are considering a career in finance and weighing up which aspects of the field excite you the most, this course is for you. By choosing this course, you will sharpen your understanding of these broad disciplines and prepare yourself with the skills and competencies that financial jobs require. You will participate in the following workshops hosted by finance companies: Pitching Training, Negotiation Training, Case-Solving Training, and a Financial Security Allocation game. In these workshops you will learn about the pillar from professionals from the field and you will practice and reflect on the concrete skills needed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Better understanding of four well-known financial job segments; (i) Accountancy, (ii) M&A, (iii) Consultancy and (iv) Asset Management.
• Better understanding of basic negotiation concepts and practical experience with negotiating a deal/agreement.
• Better understanding on how to approach a case and learning the basic steps to solve cases.
• Better understanding how to create a good pitch and practical experience with pitching.
• Better understanding of the types of financial securities and how news could influence the financial market.
• Practical experience with asset trading based on news articles.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Social inequalities are found in various settings within society. In this course, you will learn about social inequality, the biases we are prone to when it comes to social inequality and the importance of inclusive leadership to tackle inequality. We will collaborate with Stichting Werkshop (MDT op Zuid) that supports specific less privileged people impacted by extreme life experiences. In this case we will work with young status holders and support them in achieving goals like work, education, self-reliance etc. This means that this Career Skills course will be a hands-on course for which you will leave the campus and put theory in practice. Students will engage with the different leadership qualities and skills and will learn how to develop them and put them in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Have an understanding of the different inclusive leadership skills and how to apply them in practice during their current life and in their future career;

• Reflect on their growth in skills (e.g., empathy, listening, commitment, motivation and taking responsibility) and how this has an effect on their relationship with young people who are impacted by extreme life experiences.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this introduction to deliberate creativity students will learn the basic methods, principles and attitudes to apply creativity in their daily and future work, using the integrated creative problem solving (iCPS) approach. Integrated Creative Problem Solving is a three-stage approach, using deliberate creativity as a way to solve complex problems, in groups (Heijne and Van der Meer, 2019).

The strong connection with current and future practice, is established through the science-based and hands-on approach of the course. Through practicing repetitively the students will internalise the basic methods, principles and attitudes. Therefore, they can be easily applied in their day-to-day live right away and will remain relevant in their academic and/or professional career.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The students will learn to apply methods, principles and attitudes of the three stages of the iCPS approach.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105156,2022,Career Skills: Managing complexity,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['C Heese, MSc', 'RCHIM Belting']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The World Economic Forum predicts that 50% of jobs are to change in the next ten years – a trend that isn’t expected to slow down. Data abundance, automation, and global challenges are just a few of the driving factors. How can you prepare for your career when the jobs you will one day be working may not even exist yet?

One of the answers to this dilemma is learning transferable skills – skills that are useful and applicable across a variety of circumstances. Still, this requires a degree of prediction – which ones will still be applicable in the future, and, of these, which are most useful?

Overall, we can say that the world is becoming more complex – or rather, our operations are becoming more complex. Collaborations are bigger than ever before, our technological capabilities increase the horizons of what is possible, and data is abundant and (relatively) easily accessible. Your role as a knowledge worker is moving from being a knowledge holder to being a knowledge processer, where your impact comes from decomplexifying the world through effective processing, packaging, and communicating of ideas and knowledge. We are in the age of information and influence.

This course intends to prepare you for the future of work by teaching you how to effectively manage complexity. The course is structured to follow the core steps of processing information, as shown below.

• The first element is filtering input – it is about having a critical eye for information – identifying what is valuable, what is true, and what is missing. The first session will focus on critical thinking.
• Next comes processing the selected information – drawing conclusions and developing solutions. The second session will focus on problem solving.

• Finally, a solution is only useful when it can actually be implemented. As we usually won’t be operating on our own (be it teammates, customers, decision makers, or any other stakeholder), communication or dissemination of your newly developed knowledge is key. The third and fourth sessions will focus on power & politics and rhetoric respectively.

The course ends with a final session where teams must present in order to demonstrate their ability to critically assess information, process this in an interesting manner, and effectively communicate their perspective/findings.

A central design principle of the course is interaction and application – sessions will consist chiefly of discussions and application. Theory is only involved to the extent of providing language for discussion. The primary goal of this programme is the development of your mental models, not simply expanding your knowledge base.

• Critically evaluate discourse in its use/abuse of rhetorical techniques and be awareness of one’s own communication

column1: This course can help you to become more effective and to reach your goals and aspirations. First of all, you learn how to prioritise your tasks and activities and how to efficiently organise your inbox, agenda and to do-list.
We will also introduce you to various working styles and discuss what the pro's and con's of each are, especially in times of stress.

You will also learn to use your own energy sustainably and how you can recharge through active and passive forms of renewal. Lastly, you will examine your values, strengths and skills and what it means to be a T-shaped professional.
After the course you will know how to use positive self-analysis to foster personal growth and professional development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• You learn how to prioritise your tasks and activities and how to efficiently organise your inbox, agenda and to-do-list. You learn more about your working style(s), how to use the strengths that come with it and to recognise the pitfalls that arise in times of stress.

• You will understand why the sustainable use of your own energy is key to high performance. You know how to differentiate between your physical, emotional and mental capacity and how to recharge through active and passive forms of renewal.

• You will explore your values and aspirations and create scenarios for your future career. You will also learn how to set personal goals in order to bridge the gap between aspirations and productivity.

column1: In many organisations, working on projects will be part of your daily task. In this course you will learn how to become an effective project manager. You will learn what the core tasks of a project leader are, how to define and meet project requirements, goals and deliverables, and how to set up a project (including planning, divisions of labour, key deliverables and risk assessment). You will also learn more about the role you prefer to take when working in a team. You will be introduced to several team role theories. We will then focus on the 9 Belbin team roles and you will fill in a self-assessment questionnaire to explore your own team role preference.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You learn more about the topics that are fundemental to each project and the three roles that need to be fulfilled
• You learn what your core tasks are as a project leader and what tasks should be delegated or ignored
• You understand the difference between project requirements, goals and deliverables and you know how to define these
• You learn to assess whether an assignment can be turned in to a project and you learn how to set up a project (including planning, divisions of labour, key deliverables and risk assessment)

column1: Het Tax Jurisprudence Program wordt georganiseerd door Christiaanse Taxateur. Het omvat een fiscaal inhoudelijk programma bestaande uit - in beginsel - tien sessies in de loop van het collegejaar, beginnend begin oktober. Tijdens de sessies komen fiscale onderwerpen op een zeer interactieve wijze aan bod. Het is bij uitstek de kans om je fiscale kennis te verbreden en te verdiepen.

De sessies hebben een interactief karakter waarbij jij dus echt deel uitmaakt van de discussie. Verschillende kantoren zullen een vaktechnisch overleg geven waarin actuele ontwikkelingen van fiscale vakgebieden worden doorgenomen. Ook zullen verschillende casussen uitvoerig worden besproken. Het programma kenmerkt zich door een hoge mate van interactie, onderlinge uitwisseling en praktische toepasbaarheid. Immers, een vaktechnisch overleg zal je in de toekomst als fiscalist nog veel tegenkomen.

Bovendien leer je verschillende potentiële werkgevers kennen, wat bijzonder waardevol kan zijn, mocht je interesse hebben in een stage of een werkstudentschap. Ook zullen de docenten van onze vakgroepen Fiscale Economie en Fiscaal Recht een bijdrage leveren aan de avonden door middel van een analyse van relevante jurisprudentie over het desbetreffende onderwerp.

column1: Kennismaken met zowel de fiscale praktijk als de fiscale theorie. Studenten vergroten hun fiscale kennis en oefenen met skills in een oefenrechtbank en vaktechnisch-overleg.

column1: This online course is a mandatory part of the Career Skills programme.
The aim of Your Future Career is to prepare students for their career.

When you care about what you do, you will enjoy your work more, create greater impact, and be more successful. However, it can be difficult to identify what your passion is, where your competencies and skills will be useful, and which professional environment and culture are the best match for you. Therefore, the Career Skills programme offers you this online course to put you in the driver's seat of your career, and to support you in identifying your first career step and preparing for it.

The online modules of Your Future Career will help you make crucial steps towards the most suitable internship or job for you. To pass the course you need to gain 28 points by a set deadline. You can decide for yourself if you want to reflect on your interests and motivations, develop knowledge of the job market, functions, organisations and industries, or receive peer feedback on your application materials.
This online course will run from the start of block 3 till the end of block 4. You cannot start halfway the course.

• Show pro-activity in regard to career preparation
• Analyse your strengths and weaknesses, personality, values and skills
• Identify different career paths in the job market
• Identify career preparation gaps and create action points to fill the gaps
• Understand the recruitment and application process in different industries

column1: Develop and learn to communicate your personal brand

column2: • Assess how your future career can be a force for positive change
• Demonstrate written and verbal communication skills needed in the job application process

column1: Om jezelf de (zakelijke) schrijfvaardigheid eigen te maken ga je aan de hand van een combinatie van theorie en verschillende praktische opdrachten zowel individueel als in groepsverband met de leerdoelen aan de slag. Hierbij krijg je zowel feedback van elkaar als van de docent.
Daarnaast krijgen je ook algemene tips, richtlijnen en schrijfadviezen gericht op het zakelijk schrijven.
Dit vak bestaat uit zeven bijeenkomsten van twee uur. Daarnaast moet je rekenen op ongeveer 14 uur zelfstudie en voorbereiding.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106670,2022,Carriage of Goods,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. J Hornig']",,"Inhoud

The course consists of three parts. The first part (70%), is based upon a theme-by-theme analysis of carriage contract, where the various unimodal carriage conventions (Hague-Visby Rules, Hamburg Rules, CMR, CMNI, COTIF-CIM, and Montreal) are compared and contrasted to provide a deeper insight in the various subjects at hand. The second part (20%) consists of a study of capita selecta of time and voyage charterparties. The third part (10 %) gives insights of green transport and requires students to question the current transport law systems by applying the unimodal carriage conventions to unusual business models, like crowd logistics, cargo bundling and waste shipment.
The themes discussed during the lectures include:
- the role of transport in international commercial law

- a general introduction in which an overview is given of the various unimodal conventions which are part of the fragmented law of transport, and in which conceptual distinctions are made between the contracts of carriage, freight forwarding and storage as well as special kinds of contracts of carriage, such as multimodal transport contracts, contracts of affreightment,
- transport documents and related documents, such as bills of lading, way bills, delivery orders, consignment notes, charter-parties,
- Duties of the parties to the contract of carriage and contractual options
- transport related conflict of law matters,
- title to sue under contracts of carriage and bills of lading,
- bringing a claim under the conventions including limitation and notification periods as well as aspects of Brussels I Recast Regulation
- liability of the carrier, including ecological aspects of the compensation regime,
- the role of intermediaries and contractual clauses
- contract management of transport-business models in sharing economy and circular economy
Where different interpretations exist with regards to specific questions, the interpretations given by the Austrian, Dutch, English, French, German and Belgian courts are addressed.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
To provide students with the necessary knowledge and a strategy to handle cargo claims and claims relating to passenger transportation under the different conventions.
To provide students with an insight in the different interpretations of carriage law in national case law, to allow them to make an assessment of the most suitable court for the specific claim.

To encourage students to combine innovative sustainable transport models with the learned legal system and find gaps in the existing systems (e.g. with regards to the contract of carriage, with the value-dependency of compensation).</body>

column1: In many industries the dynamics of competition are constantly changing as a result of technological innovations and new business models. While some companies manage to adapt to new developments, many previously successful companies fail to do so and lose their competitiveness. What differentiates these two groups of companies? This course focuses on how companies can successfully adapt their offerings and business models to the changing competitive landscape. We will first examine why once-great companies could not sustain their competitiveness despite their established positions in their industries. We will then focus on two important capabilities to strategically change a business: to adopt new business models by re-organizing existing competencies in innovative ways, and to locate and benefit from new knowledge outside the company to develop new competencies. We will then analyze how leaders can influence the success or failure of strategic change. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge about navigating an increasingly complex competitive landscape and to apply it through case discussions and group exercises. Throughout the course there will be a healthy mix of theory and its application in real-life cases.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After finishing this course students will be able to:

column2: • Analyze why previously successful companies fail to sustain their competitiveness in the wake of new technological and/or business model innovations;
• Develop ideas to revise a company’s business model to leverage its core competencies in innovative ways;
• Appraise the value of external knowledge for innovation and identify appropriate sources for valuable external knowledge;
• Define a company`s innovation ecosystem and describe the role of complementary external parties in developing new strategies to maintain competitive advantage;
• Select appropriate leadership practices to guide a company through strategic change;
• Analyze: (a) developments that change the dynamics of competition; and (b) ideas to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
• Create, evaluate and make decisions about options for new strategies and business models to: (a) respond to changing dynamics of competition; and (b) leverage core competencies.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109234,2022,Changing a Mature Business,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. R Kanitz', 'R Pichler, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Navigating organizational change is a fundamental theme in the social sciences. Its relevance for managers grows with challenges that arise from coping with competitive markets, shifting societal values, and evolving technologies. As you assume greater responsibilities in your career, you will need to drive necessary change in your organizations. You as potential leaders must, with increasing urgency, encourage other people to engage with change. Yet, this is easier said than done as exemplified by high numbers of initiatives failing to produce the intended results in practice. The necessity for managing change seems obvious, theories and tools for navigating change are elusive. The objective of this course is, hence, to explore how change works in organizations. In the first part of the course, we will build on current theories and discuss how four interrelated processes — envisioning, assessing, mobilizing, and institutionalizing — may help to better think through the complexity of change. In the second part of the course, you will deep dive into societal megatrends as drivers of change and reflect on how environmental regulations and shifting societal values drive change in organizations. Taken together, the course aims to enable students to develop an evidence-based mind-set on managing change. This course completes the business developer track.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Understand and explain core theories and models to navigate organizational change (content-related)
• Differentiate and apply concepts related to the envisioning, assessing, mobilizing, and institutionalizing during organizational change (skill-related)
• Adopt an evidence-based mindset to design recommendations to navigate change in organizations (attitude-related)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106718,2022,Charter Parties & Bills of Lading,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. J Hornig']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Merchant vessels are meant to make money for their owners. Very often, ship owners do that by renting out their ships (with or without a crew) to other parties that have a use for that ship. A general term for such contracts is 'contract of affreightment'. Within that general category, there are two main types of contracts: charter parties on the one hand, bills of lading on the other hand.

This course first looks at charter parties, which exist in different varieties (mainly bareboat, time and voyage charter parties). The rights and obligations of the charterer and of the ship owner are studied.

In the second part of the course, Bills of Lading are studied. A Bill of Lading can be issued under a charter party, but can also be (evidence of) a contract of carriage on its own. Bills of Lading are very important in international trade and for the financing of such trade. The course will look at the nature and characteristics of the Bill of Lading as a document of title, and will look at the rights and obligations of the parties to a contract of carriage under a Bill of Lading, although the liability regime of a carrier under Bills of Lading is also covered in ‘Transport Law’ (RB72).

Carriage of goods by sea is often governed by international conventions such as the Hague (Visby) Rules, the Hamburg Rules and the Rotterdam Rules, which have a major impact on those rights and obligations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To provide students with an overview and understanding of the legal issues relating to the commercial operation of cargo ships. The first part of the course deals with Charter Parties, which are contracts for the use of a vessel.  The second part of the course deals with the Bill of Lading as one of the most important transport documents used in international trade and transport.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103751,2022,Cheap: A Critique of Capitalism in the Web of Life,Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course traces the genealogy of the seven 'cheap' things that have made our modern world: nature, money, work, care, food, energy and lives. Capitalism cannot exist without these seven cheaps.

In examining the seven cheaps, the course provides a new understanding of capitalism as a ‘worldecology’ of power, capital and nature. Capitalism’s greatest strength and the source of its problems is its capacity to make the world cheap and safe for itself: by creating and mobilizing geological, botanical, animal and human forces and putting them to work – as cheaply as possible.

However, the web of life cannot exist in a world-ecology designed by and for capitalism. Tracing the history and practices of resistance by slaves, women, indigenous people, workers, animals and other actants in the web of life, the course outlines a program of resistance (i.e., a way of thinking beyond the cheap things and strategies that capitalism’s ecology has spawned) that includes recognition, reparation, redistribution, reimagination and recreation.

Drawing on cutting-edge ecological research, feminist philosophy, heterodox political economics, post-colonial theory and following Jason W. Moore’s groundbreaking work on capitalism as worldecology, this course proposes a radical new way of analyzing today’s planetary emergencies and a new way of reclaiming the planet and our future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After this course, students will be able to:
- Conceptually define colonialism, neo-colonialism, imperialism and postcolonialism.
- Understand and describe some of the major ideas in postcolonialism, like Edward Said's Orientalism.
- Understand and describe some of the major theoretical debates within postcolonialsm.
- Understand and describe some of the concepts that are linked to decolonisation of culture, land and the mind.
- Understand and describe the present-day relevancy of the vantages that postcolonialism offers.</body>

• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Chinees gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.

column1: Deze cursus bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Chinees beginners 2?

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus ben je in staat om naast bovengenoemde punten, ongeveer 160 woorden in Pinyin te schrijven en ken je 20 Chinese basiskarakters. Daarnaast beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat, waarmee je eenvoudige zinnen leert formuleren waarmee je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is beginners 1, vergelijkbaar met het A1.1 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Over the past few decades, scholars from multiple disciplines (psychology, economics, organizational behaviour and marketing) have gained deeper insight into how consumers make choices, including the non-economic features of the choice environment that can influence people’s choices (e.g., default decisions, displayed font). Many of these insights have challenged the traditional assumption that people make choices primarily in a rational, self-interested manner. These research programs have provided novel insight into how people deviate from “optimal” choices and the consequences of these “sub-optimal” choices.

Because these decision strategies and mindsets often lead to choices that have harmful consequences for business, society and consumer welfare, it is important that students as future business leaders a) understand the basic principles of consumer decision making and b) have the tools to implement strategies that change consumer choice in the desired manner (dubbed nudging). Doing so will help them in numerous ways, including (but not limited to): a) making them a better decision maker in your personal and professional life, b) improving their ability to attract and retain satisfied customers and c) ensuring that their business runs smoothly.

Although there may be some overlap with contents typically seen in marketing courses on communication and advertising, Choice Architecture course provides a substantially different approach to understanding and changing consumer choice. Specifically, the current course will draw primarily from behavioural economics research, will be geared towards making sustainable choices at the individual, business, and societal levels, and will be aimed at developing choice-intervention strategies that can be implemented in a wide variety of contexts: one-on-one negotiations, team organization, risk management, policy design, among others, as well as more classic communication arenas such as social marketing.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recognize core tenants of normative and descriptive models of choice
• Recognize core tenants of dual-process theories of cognition
• Be able to differentiate between different types of heuristics
• Be able to differentiate between different types of systematic biases
• Analyse novel decision contexts to figure out what aspects of the decision context lead to peoples’ current choices.
• Evaluate the monetary and psychological costs of the intervention
• Debate whether the intervention is ethical or not.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106489,2022,Cinema and Society,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: An industry, a media and an art, cinema is mostly enjoyed as a form of entertainment. Studying movies, unlike literature or painting, is often seen as a waste of time and an anomaly in higher education. Yet, the power of cinema to convince, to move audiences, and to provide influential stories should be carefully studied. This course will use several movies to understand their social significance, and how societies have replaced ancient mythologies with modern images.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Using a combination of case studies and film history, Cinema and Society intends to help students appreciate cinema and its effects on societies. Movies from different eras and societies will be used to provide students with a better understanding of cinema.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106491,2022,Cinemas in Context,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Each week in “Cinemas in Context”, a different movie will be analyzed to understand its roots, context, place in pop culture, and future in high culture. Focus will be on movies able to create their own universe, hence the subtitle “Deep universes”. Using a combination of students’ research, lecturing and tutoring, the seminar aims to contribute to a better understanding of cinema from an academic and artistic point of view. At the end of the seminar, students will be able to understand several movies’ universes provided in the curriculum, along with some they will choose themselves.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>""Cinemas in Context: Deep Universes"" intends to contribute to the understanding of film studies by exposing students to in-depth research in cinema as an art and an expression of culture.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Circular Economy has rapidly become a buzzword, but it is not always clear how it should affect corporations, organizations, or society as a whole.

This course aims to bring conceptual clarity and develop practical knowledge of circular solutions. The Circular Economy is then explored from both an applied and theoretical perspective while looking at strategies, foundational ideas, and business models. Several examples and case studies will illustrate different views on the Circular Economy, including barriers and enabling conditions.

The course consists of in-class lectures, some of which given by guest lecturers from the government or innovative companies, as well as three assignments: An in-class group presentation and short group report– both based on real business cases – and an individual report.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding the fundamental ideas, concepts, principles, barriers/enabling conditions, strategies, applications and business models of the circular economy.
• Designing, validating, improving and applying circular economy solutions within the value chain and lifecycle of products across different business contexts.
• Developing a solution-oriented mindset toward circular economy challenges both as an individual and in work teams.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109257,2022,Circular and Digital Business Design,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. HWGM van Heck'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Foundational information technologies, in particular, Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms, Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, and Blockchain infrastructure, will create new foundations for business and its interaction among businesses, governments, customers, and the earth. These technologies will create opportunities for circular business models, i.e., to do business within the ecological and planetary boundaries of the earth. Instead of the ‘take, make, and dispose’ attitude of the traditional and linear business, circular business will create value with the design of ‘recycle, refurbish, reuse, and maintain’ processes. Both the circular and digital transformation will influence customer relationships, redefine products and services, change the operations and value chain processes, enable new ways of collaboration in business ecosystems, and will shift the information frontier further, with fresh, fast, and more reliable information relevant for circular business models. Next generation business models will need to develop both the circular and digital capabilities in a holistic configuration of people, processes, and technologies.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first goal of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of the differences between linear and circular business and between digitizing and digital business. Different circular processes, i.e., recycle, refurbish, reuse, and maintenance, are explained and different business models and business examples are discussed. Special attention will be paid to potential information needs and the provision of information by three foundational information technologies, e.g., AI, IoT, and Blockchain.

The second goal of the course is for students to learn how to analyze and evaluate circular and digital business models in such a way that three performance dimensions will improve, i.e., people (customers, employees, partners), planet (natural resources), and prosperity of the local and global society. Examples in floriculture, energy, fashion, manufacturing, retail, trade and transport will be discussed.
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain the importance of circular and digital business within the social foundation and ecological ceiling of the Earth.
• Analyze and evaluate the circular and digital design dimensions of business models

• Understand and identify the circular information needs and the provision of these needs by foundational information technologies, in particular, Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms, Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, and Blockchain infrastructure.
• Understand and apply the circular and digital business design knowledge in real-life business cases.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. S.J.G. van Wijnbergen (UvA), Prof. F. van der Ploeg (Oxford Un, UvA)

This course focuses on climate change: one of the greatest challenges of our time. What can the science of economics teach us about its causes and potential solutions? What are the costs and benefits of climate change? Its impact on poverty? Should we tax carbon, cap-and-trade emission rights, or subsidize solar and wind power? Does the answer depend on how we value the future? Why/when should we discount the distant future less than the proximate future? What is the impact of risk and true uncertainty (ambiguity) on the discount rate? Can a tradeoff between growth and the environment be avoided, and if so with what sort of policies? Does trade harm the environment? Will our industry move abroad if we take a leading role and 'go it alone'? Can well-intended climate policies actually accelerate global warming? What are good second-best climate policies? How to deal with climate tipping points? What is the international incidence of climate change and of the climate policies needed to combat it? Why is it so difficult to negotiate international agreements?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After having completed this course, you will know the answers to the above questions, or at least you will be able to have an informed opinion; and you will be able to enter into the economic policy debate well informed.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114558,2022,Climate change strategy roleplay,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SP Kennedy'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Climate change is one of today’s most pressing issues, receiving international attention from political leaders, corporations, the media, advocacy groups, and the general public. In the future, it is likely to become even more pressing as the effects of climate change intensify resource competition, natural disasters, disease vectors, water and food scarcity, and refugee migration.

According to Sir Nicholas Stern, former chief economist of the World Bank, the impact of climate change is likely to change the international business environment dramatically. However, the business relevance of climate change is insufficiently understood by future decision makers in international management and society.

We believe that tomorrow’s business leaders should be educated on the key elements of climate change –the science, the evolving policy, and role of business. They can become an essential part of the solution, but only if equipped with a sound understanding of the challenges at hand and the processes by which new policies are constructed.

The Climate Change Strategy course and its Model United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) form an innovative educational approach to closing this knowledge gap. Our goal is to broaden students' understanding of climate change, climate policy, and their impacts on the future of business.

The course modules deal with the core issues of climate change and include a wide range of effective didactic tools and exercises. Students are given a deeper understanding of the background and consequences of climate change for business, and of corporate responses to it. Special emphasis is laid on international and national regulatory frameworks, and on emerging resource challenges and market opportunities. Furthermore, the course will provide students with an opportunity to develop a broad set of personal skills such as negotiation, forming strategy, research, public speaking and debating.

The 2021edition of the course will be simultaneously offered at eight leading CEMS universities and culminates in a two-day UNFCCC simulation event at one of the business schools. Students will be using the 2015 Paris Agreement created at COP21 and be simulating the upcoming COP27. Negotiations will seek to enhance the current Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of countries and work out details of how the new mechanisms and funds will function. The big challenge is how to improve the current commitments to be in line with the universally agreed target of limiting global temperature rise to ‘well-below 2 degrees’.

Students will negotiate on issues such as mitigation of greenhouse gases (new voluntary targets, financing and compliance), adaptation to climate change (financing, climate change refugees, technology transfer), and market mechanisms (sustainable development mechanism, REDD+, aviation and shipping).
Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.
This course assumes no prior knowledge of climate change or of climate change policy. The course is divided into four modules:

column2: • Module 1 gives an extensive introduction to the topic of climate change and climate policy and will include a guest lecture from a notable climatologist.
• Module 2 will highlight the role of business in climate change and will include a guest speakers from industry.

• Module 3 prepares students for the role-play including negotiation skills training. Students gain insights in negotiation theory and acquire skills of looking beyond positions to the underlying interest of a party.
• Module 4 consists of an online simulation with all participating universities.

column1: Midterm, roles for the negotiation simulation will be assigned to all students. In line with the innovative three-sector approach of this course, each student will either represent a government delegate, a non-governmental organization or a lobbyist from industry. This approach aims to provide experience not only in inter-governmental debate of climate change issues, but also in the way civil society and business interests can influence these discussions.
Example blog of the Role Play in 2016, written by the fictitious media team: https://unfcccnegotiations2016.wordpress.com
UN Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME) LEADERS+20 Competition Top 10 Placing for the course:
News articles relating to the 2018 Climate change role-play (Model UNFCCC):

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this module the participant is able to:

column2: • Understand the negotiation process under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
• Explain the roles and interests of the private sector, government and civil society in tackling climate change.
• Formulate a negotiation strategy for climate change negotiations.
• Apply negotiation skills in an international negotiations setting
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The ability to communicate effectively is very important for many professional practitioners. Professional communication differs from normal communication in a number of ways, for example by using professional interviews. Professional interviews have a clear purpose and how the interview is led and carried out should be geared towards achieving that goal. Good problem clarification, for example, is a condition of a good professional therapy or advice session. Furthermore, the client can expect that a professional takes the greatest care in dealing with his or her personal problems, which can be very sensitive issues. A number of basic communication skills and a good basic attitude are needed in order to achieve this goal. So, the aim of this course is to improve the knowledge and skills required for effective communication. Theory and research on communication is reviewed and basic attitudes and basic interviewing skills are practised in role-plays. Note. This course is not about the clinical interview as a tool for diagnosing clients.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The Clinical Communication Skills course will:

column5: Help you gain insight into the processes in counselling a person with a request for help.
Help you gain insight into and knowledge of the Van der Molen, Lang, Trower & Look (2014) interview model and how to use this model
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the concrete skills needed to help a person with a problem
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the adequate use of these interviewing skills

Deepen your knowledge in cultural differences that exist between (counsellors and) clients in perceptions of mental illnesses and help you gain insight into the multicultural counseling competencies needed to help clients from different cultures.
