column1: The statistics are very clear and pressing: if we want to reach the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we still have a funding gap of a $ 2.5 trillion annually. We therefore need to find other ways to invest in the SDGs and to scale the impact as merely financial resources will not suffice. An increasingly relevant player in this field are Corporate Social Investors (CSIs); e.g. corporate foundations, corporate social impact funds and corporate social accelerators.

Why? Because these CSIs operate in between the business and the ultimate beneficiary and are in the unique position to leverage corporate resources such as financial means, products, services, technology and the corporate network for the public good. As companies realize that by only pursuing commercial strategies, our wicked problems will not be resolved, an increasing number of companies are implementing non-commercial strategies to contribute to society.

Indeed, CSI’s are formalized in a separate legal structure to safeguard that they put social impact at the core of their activities rather than financial return. As such, CSIs are aimed at “transforming patterns of thought, behaviour, social relationships, institutions, and social structure to generate beneficial outcomes for individuals, communities, organisations, society, and/or the environment beyond the benefits for the instigators of such transformation” (Stephan et al., 2016, p. 1252; italics added).

The aim of this course is to introduce students to Corporate Social Investments where social impact is at the core of the activities, rather than the financial return. We will discuss why companies pursue this strategy and why they set up these organizational structures. What is the role of these CSIs in society? What are their strategies? What can they do that the company cannot? And, how are these CSIs managed efficiently and effectively?
Module 1: Introduction and Corporate Social Investors in Europe
Module 2: Impact Only, Impact first or Finance First?
Module 6: Contemporary modes of corporate social investments.

In each module, we will be joined by an expert from the field. Guest lecturers in 2022 included representatives of Ikea Social Entrepreneurship, Philips Foundation, the Chocolonely Foundation, and Human Safety Net among others.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After attending the theoretical classes, the practical guest lectures, and after completing the assignments that this class will offer, the student will be able to:

column2: • Understand why, when and how businesses choose for non-commercial strategies to create positive social change.
• Explain the difference between finance first (or only) and impact first (or only) strategies and when (not) to pursue one above the other.
• Argue why corporate social investors are (not) needed when companies implement their sustainability agenda (and/or adopt SDGs).
• Apply various theories (mostly organizational behavior theories) around corporate social investment on contemporary managerial issues of corporate social investors.
• Defend and be critical towards an impact-first or impact only strategy that companies may seek in their sustainability portfolio.

column1: In today's world competitive advantages erode faster and faster. Globalization, technological development and industry convergence pressure organizations to put more emphasis on corporate strategy. Corporate strategy revolves around the 4 themes of boundaries, diversification, synergy, and innovation. Traditionally, corporate strategy involves the choice in which markets a company is active and managers decided mainly about diversification and resource allocation. These days corporate strategy also concerns leveraging resources across a company’s businesses to create both cost-reducing and value-enhancing synergies and to spur innovation. To get access to relevant resources they do not possess, firms increasingly look beyond their boundaries and seek to acquire and ally with organizations. Such corporate development decisions have become an essential activity of corporate strategy, making corporate development departments central units in many organizations.

The objective of this course is to help participants develop a conceptual and practical understanding of corporate strategy and the role of corporate development. After successfully completing the course, students will have to their availability a toolkit and skills that help them steer corporate strategy decisions. This includes tools to assess, transform and organize a corporate portfolio of businesses. It also includes tools to make a choice between acquisitions and alliances, and attention will be paid to the implications and managerial challenges alliances and acquisitions pose by addressing the levers of successfully creating value, selecting targets and partners, integrating acquisition targets and controlling alliances. Finally, in addition to accessing new resources through alliances and acquisitions, the shedding of resources through corporate divestments will be addressed. As part of the skills trajectory across the core courses, this course develops two important corporate skills: portfolio analysis and target valuation. Overall, the course develops state-of-the-art understanding of the risks and returns associated with corporate strategy and corporate development, and the managerial skills and capabilities needed to be successful.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing the course, the student will have learning the following:

column2: • Identify and compare relevant theoretical concepts and frameworks of corporate strategy, corporate development and growth
• Integrate theoretical insights and frameworks that shape (1) boundary, (2) diversification, (3) synergy and (4) innovation decisions in corporate development
• Apply theoretical insights and frameworks to practical corporate development cases and situations
• Collect data and information relevant to corporate development decisions
• Analyze opportunities and challenges to develop strategic options for corporate portfolio and ownership decisions
• Value target companies in corporate growth situations
• Propose a corporate strategy and implementation plan for a company as a corporate strategy team
• Demonstrate the ability to work with incomplete information in an ethical way

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Over the past years, small firms and start-ups have started to play an increasingly important role in our economy. R&D spending by small firms has increased and many disruptive innovations have been conceived by new entrants to an industry, thereby posing a major threat to existing firms. In order to sustain their competitive advantage, it is important for large firms such as Shell, DSM, and KLM to tap into the knowledge of these start-ups and to invest in corporate venturing. Corporate venturing can be achieved in different ways, including: taking a minority position in outside businesses (corporate venture capital), building a new business as a stand-alone unit (spin-out), or building a new business inside the existing firm with a structure allowing for managerial autonomy and independence (corporate incubator or accelerator). This course will discuss strategies, organizational structures and implementation challenges of new ventures within an established corporation as well as options to leverage external partners outside the boundaries of the corporation within the process of new business development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the different forms of corporate venturing and how each of them advances the corporate innovation
• Identify key trends and organizational practices of corporate venturing
• Describe the importance of corporate venturing and the various ways in which it can be organized and recognized within companies
• Demonstrate a multidisciplinary view on corporate venturing and open innovation

column1: This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making and will dive into questions such as: whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.

Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following this course, students will be able to

column2: • Analyse the connection between risk of an asset and expected return of an asset and be able to apply the CAPM correctly.
• Describe the different forms of market efficiency and explain their relevance for understanding stock price movements.
• Calculate the value of a company that is financed with equity and debt based on an analysis of the relevant cash flows.
• Analyse the impact of dividend policy on the value of companies.
• Apply complex financial instruments (futures and options, convertible bonds and warrants) in the context of risk management.
• Apply pricing models of complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
• Describe and analyze the underlying mechanisms of short-term financing.
• Calculate and interpret the most important metrics used in short-term financing.

column1: Analysis of flow cytometry data is getting more and more complex due to increased parameters that can be measured on a single sample.
High dimensional analysis software can help to properly and systematically analyze big flow cytometry datasets.
This course on high dimensional analysis of flow cytometry data provides theoretical background in high dimensional analysis,
will discuss the pros and cons of available software and will help you decide what program is best for you.
What do you have to do with your samples, what kind of quality control, what kind of tools/methods are available, what are advantages and disadvantages of the respective methods.
How do you decide what program is most suitable for you?
Day 2: Will go into different programs that are generally used for high dimensional analysis of flow cytometry data, amongst others tSNE, Cyclospore, FlowSOM and Euroflow pipeline.
The ins and outs, as well as the pro and cons of the programs will be discussed.

column1: Welcome to the Business Developer Track! The aim of this track is to take you through the life-cycle of an organization in pursuit of generating value for its customers and other stakeholders. The track will take you through the first step of idea generation and selection, the second step of growing an emerging business, and the third step of engineering its adaptive change. Each of these three steps will be taught in self-containing modules of ‘Create’, ‘Grow’, and ‘Change’.

This is ‘Create’, the first module of the Business Developer Track. In this module, you will understand the factors that foster or hinder idea generation for businesses. The course provides a multi-disciplinary background on generating novel and useful product-, customer-, and society-driven ideas. The course also provides necessary background on the techniques for selecting the right ideas and proper and methodologies for properly implementing them in the first steps of the innovation process.

The module is designed to help you build your knowledge based on a mix of no-nonsense academic knowledge and real-world applications. You will have the opportunity to better understand the relevant frameworks and methods by applying them to practice through case-based discussions and group projects. For those participants, who would like to dig deeper into the topics, there will also be additional (optional) material for personal development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Understand factors that foster or hinder idea generation in the business context
• Understand ideation in the new product development process
• Understand how ideas can combine commercial and positive social impact
• Understand techniques that promote the selection of right ideas
• Understand methodologies that ensure proper idea implementation

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109117,2022,Creating Societal Impact through Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['SM Musa, MSc', 'YT Wiessner, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The long prevailing assumptions of corporate market capitalism, (e.g., profit as the fundamental purpose of business (Friedman, 1970), opportunism as the key feature of managers’ behavior (Jensen & Meckling, 1976), and competition as the key process for reaching prosperity (Porter, 1998)) have recently come under serious questions. According to the Deloitte Human Capital Trends 2018 report, 77% of business and HR leaders around the world rate “citizenship and social impact” as important or critical to their strategy and identity as a corporation. The same report also noted that 86% of millennials believe the success of a business should not just be measured by financial performance. In general, people now are more concerned about climate change, social justice, inequality, corruption, terrorism, mass migration etc. Interestingly, though very powerful actors of capitalist society, businesses have long been able to ditch these issues in conducting their business operations, leaving them entirely to the hands of politicians and public sector actors. But not anymore! For their own survival businesses need to address these challenges.  But how do they do so? How do social entrepreneurs tackle grand social, political and environmental challenges? How do they create measurable social impact and business opportunity? This course is designed to seek answers to these questions and equip students with tools and strategies to create social impact around the world and be the force of positive change in the society. Throughout the course students will be given a tour to the Impact World and in the process, they will enrich their theoretical and practical knowledge on impact leadership and strategies.

At the end of the course students will have a very good understanding on: 1. How can businesses reach beyond profit in a capitalist system? 2. What type of leadership is necessary and what type of organizing is required for creating social impact? 3. How do the impact processes work, and how to measure and scale up social impact?

The Beyond Profits and Promise elective is shared between two lecturers from the Department of Strategic Management and Entrepreneurship. Both lecturers bring in their own personal angle on social impact and accordingly the students will be exposed to a diverse set of elements that constitute the ‘bigger picture’. Each week will feature a three-hour lecture that centers on a specific theme regarding strategies and organizing for social impact. To complement theoretical considerations, we allow students to gain practical insights into the realities of social impact creation through

In terms of preparation, students are required to read at least the required literature as stated in the course overview and prepare for the quizzes featured in each lecture. In terms of examination, beyond the quizzes, groups of students are required to write a Research Report on an impact project of their choice. Moreover, students will write individual reflections on the process of their impact project, as well as a short case study applying insights from the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course will provide knowledge and examples that allows students to:
•         Gain a theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of impact strategies
•         Critically compare different impact-creating organizational forms
•         Understand the ‘real-life’ challenges and limitations to creating impact
•         Understand the underlying logic and meaning of impact measurement
•         Apply theoretical insights formulating an impact project
•         Conceptualize and analyze the underlying foundation of existing projects

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What makes a city creative? In this research workshop, we will answer this question by reviewing and critically assessing theoretical and policy debates that have addressed this question, and by carrying out original empirical research on the topic. Over the past decades, the concept of creative city has encapsulated the anticipation of the economic and social benefits of the arts and the creative industries and their embeddedness in cities, resulting in a number of urban cultural policy interventions. More recently, cities are called upon to be creative in tackling societal challenges, from rising inequalities to the climate crisis. We will start the course by reviewing a number of central writings on creative cities. Students then develop their own original research on an aspect of creative cities, training the qualitative research skills gained in this course. Possible topics for research projects include: exploring clusters of creativity and making in the city; sustainable and inclusive practices in the arts and creative industries; arts, the creative industries and urban gentrification.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between creativity, cultural production and consumption, and cities. Secondly, students train their qualitative research skills, practicing the different stages of research design. Finally, students apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to developing and conducting a small qualitative research on the topic of creative cities, presented in oral and written form.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106394,2022,Creative Economy and Creative Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AM Damaso'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The economy is changing. Creativity is increasingly seen as a source of competitive advantage and creative assets (such as knowledge, intellectual property, networks, and technology) are increasingly seen as potential generators of economic growth. This course examines this shift in the economy through an organizational lens. Topics include: concepts of creativity; the relationship between creativity and innovation; theories on organizational creativity; distinguishing characteristics of organizations in the creative industries; creative entrepreneurship; how organizations balance the pursuit of creativity against other goals; how managers both foster and (inadvertently) kill creativity; and the nature of creative work, including labor conditions for creative workers.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of an economy based on ideas rather than physical goods and the role of organizations in this creative economy. After the course, students will be able to explain how the creative or knowledge economy is different from a goods and services based economy, and how the role of organizations changes accordingly. Students will be able to explain how creative organizations are different from other organizations, and how creativity can be fostered within organizations. After the course students will be able to apply these insights in their analysis of creative organizations in a knowledge-based economy.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106436,2022,Creative Industries in the Global Economy,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. MF van Dijck', 'JR Fear']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Cultural and creative industries are increasingly recognized as important generators of revenues and jobs, as well as powerful drivers of cultural globalization, especially as the world moves into the digital age. One 2015 global survey estimated that they created $2.2 trillion in revenue and around 30 million jobs. Yet they are not new phenomenon. The high profile of multinational media companies is often described as dominance and cultural homogenization, yet it disguises the diversity and multipolar nature of the creative industries. Countries and cities have increasingly identified creative industries as an important means of economic development; cultural branding and have increasingly used historical ""heritage"" as a competitive advantage. We will critically examine the concept of creative industries and the ""creative class,"" how digitalization has made monetization more difficult and altered industry dynamics, and the relationship between cultural industries and development. The course examines why clusters and entrepreneurs emerge at specific points in time (such as Hollywood or Bollywood) and discusses how their competitiveness can be sustained. A special focus will be on how individual firms or clusters in specific places have emerged over time and altered their strategies to redesign themselves for a global digital age.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
·         Students are able to examine critically the concept, history and reality of creative industries.
·         Students understand the particularly dynamics of various creative industries over time, in particular how digitalization is changing these industries.
·         Students can assess and explain how public policy has targeted creative industries as drivers of growth, employment, and development.
·         Students can apply key concepts such as the ""gig economy,"" ""precariat,"" and ""creative class,"" in the analysis of firm-level strategies.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106564,2022,Creative Labour,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YGD Wijngaarden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Creativity is one of the most desired aspects of modern work and creativity is seen as central to contemporary work practices. Specifically, jobs in the media and cultural industries are often considered to be the most creative of all. The recent interest in the 'creative industries', as well as the rising number of jobs in these sectors call for renewed attention to the nature of creative work in the media. Creativity requires other working conditions and skills than “regular” work and is often organized differently, with a large number of self-employed entrepreneurs and work that often tends to be project-based.

Creative industries’ policies tend to focus on the increase in the number of jobs, based on expanding the conditions for symbolic creativity. For (economic) policy, creativity is objectified as an ‘input’ in order to generate jobs and marketable products – ‘output’. In response, several analysts have pointed to serious problems concerning jobs and professions in these industries, such as uncertainty and 'precariousness'.

In this course we will critically assess the specificities of creative labour and the conditions under which it may thrive. We will identify possible drawbacks and benefits to creative employment and we will look at the nature of creative employment, drawing on contemporary work practices. Students will also gain knowledge and understanding of their future areas of employment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course, students will have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives on creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
• Apply relevant theoretical insights in the analysis of creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
• Critically assess various texts (academic texts, industry reports, policy documents) addressing creative labour;
• Set up an academic argument on creative labour, both verbally and in writing.
• Reflect on and make informed choices regarding their future careers.

column1: What makes a city creative and sustainable? And what role do the arts and culture play in this? In this research workshop, we will delve into these question by reviewing and critically assessing relevant theoretical contributions and policy debates, and by carrying out original empirical research on the topic.

Over the past decades, the concept of creative city has encapsulated the anticipation of the economic and social benefits of the arts and the creative industries and their embeddedness in cities, resulting in a number of urban cultural policy interventions. More recently, cities are called upon to be creative in tackling societal challenges, from rising inequalities to the climate crisis. We will start the course by reviewing a number of central writings on creative and sustainable urban development; we will then zoom into the cultural and artistic sectors, to see the opportunities and challenges they face towards sustainability transitions. In parallel to these content-focused discussions, we will learn about and train research methods of qualitative data collection and analysis.

Students then work in groups and individually to develop their own original research on an empirical case relating to creative and sustainable cities. Students will train the qualitative research skills gained in this course. Possible topics for research projects include: sustainable practices in the art institutions; greening and inclusive business models in the creative industries; arts, the creative industries and urban gentrification

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between creativity, sustainability, and cities. Secondly, students train their qualitative research skills, practicing the different stages of research design. Finally, students work individually and in group apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to develop and conduct a small qualitative research on the topic of creative cities, presented in oral and written form

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the first half of the twentieth century, philosophy of science was completely mesmerized by justification. Think, for instance, of verificationism and falsificationism. In this context, the emphasis was on the critical part of scientific reasoning. By contrast, in the second half of the twentieth century, with Hanson, Kuhn, and so on, the focus shifted (again) to discovery. “Friends of discovery” like Nancy Nersessian and Thomas Nickles (still) investigate the creative problem solving part of scientific reasoning. In this course, we discuss the insights and results of the friends of discovery, and reflect on how philosophy in general and philosophy of science in particular can further scientific progress, for instance, by optimizing the heuristics of creative, scientific problem solving, or by boosting or even creating conceptual integration in interdisciplinary contexts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

(2) The student can analyse, evaluate and discuss the main arguments and views in the philosophy of discovery. (30%)
(3) The student can creatively define and re(de)fine a research problem. (30%)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is an extensive literature on both creativity and innovation and their relation. The definition of creativity and innovation is overly discussed yet not conclusively. In addition, scholars and practitioners have an ongoing debate on creativity’s relation and influence within human (personal) and business development.

Creativity has its own meaning within education, psychology, business and management, marketing, communications, advertising, arts and entrepreneurship for instance. Depending on which context we take as a framework for creativity, the meaning, the practice and the outcome might differ. The same can be said about when defining what innovation might be. For the same reason, scholars argue for a ‘multidisciplinary definition of innovation’ (Baregheh et al., 2009).

To narrow down the comprehensive reach of creativity and innovation within the 21st century’s context, this seminar will focus on creative thinking (CT) & creative problem solving (CPS) theories, methods and applications in more specific. CT and CPS in a 21st century (business) context will benefit students by introducing, understanding and applying essential contemporary knowledge and skills. Besides CT & CPS being a central 21st century personal skill that is required within the work field, it is also a central practice of businesses in coming up with innovative ideas, improvements and thus solutions for product, service and communication/ human related (business) matters/ challenges.

CT & CPS, both can be related to the ‘creative person’, the creative process, the creative output (products & services) and the creative environment that either facilitates or blocks thus hinders these aspects/ processes. Several (scientific and work) fields can be directly related to these researches and practices. To name a few: Organizational-, business-, product development & communication, organizational and business sustainability, management and leadership-, creativity and innovation studies, communication sciences, (positive) psychology, entrepreneurship, marketing & sales, not to mention people’s career and lives’ in an ever-changing social, societal, economic, political, cultural context. In addition to communication, collaboration is also at the core of CT & CPS processes in a group setting.

Consequently, in this seminar, the focus will be a careful selection of creativity & innovation (CT & CPS) related theories, methods and the practice of those, applicable within several fields of work (and life in general). A solid theoretical backbone will serve for the practical implementation, geared towards a sustainable career development and business operation; product, people and process innovation.

Anahita Baregheh, Jennifer Rowley, Sally Sambrook, (2009) ""Towards a multidisciplinary definition of innovation"", Management Decision, Vol. 47 Issue: 8, pp.1323-1339, https://doi.org/10.1108/00251740910984578

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Essential theories and methods about creativity & innovation in relation to creative thinking (CT) and creative problem solving (CPS) within a globalized 21st century organizational, team and individual context

• Realizing the need for contextual awareness to apply creativity and realize innovation (that is ‘out of the box’), feasible and sustainable (for ex.: understanding the importance of the organizational, team and individual context and realizing the implications of historical, political, socio-economic, (multi / inter) cultural, industry or sector/ field related context)

• Identifying challenges and problems (within an organizational, team and individual setting) and how to differentiate between solvable difficulties to overcome, to transform, and difficulties / situations that need a complete new approach and a solution leaving the ‘old’ behind
• Knowledge of how to effectively produce and communicate (verbally and in writing) creative & innovative ideas, processes and outcomes (consultancy project)

• Understanding the need and benefits of a responsive, open, positive attitude and a curious mind-set, allowing out of the box (creative) ideas or (novel) solutions to emerge that fit the ethical framework of the situation / context
• Understanding the benefits of collaboration and own individual responsibility within a multicultural / intercultural context
• To be able to (re)define, elaborate, refine, analyse, and evaluate one’s own ideas to improve and maximize creative (individual and group) efforts within a multicultural setting

• How to gather (research) and implement methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To theorize (research, analyse, write and verbalize) creativity and innovation in a 21st century’s international / multicultural / intercultural business

• To contextualize theoretical knowledge within an empirical framework. Bringing theory into practice: To create novel solutions to existing and or foreseeable (personal, team and multicultural organizational) challenges

• To make judgments on why, where, when and how creativity and/or innovation could take place: To implement the presented methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To practice critical and analytic skills, while listening, observing, writing, verbalizing the context of multidimensional possibilities within which creativity and innovation can take place

• Understanding the necessity of a high level of interaction, and when necessary (creatively) enhance collaboration to develop, implement, and communicate new ideas to others effectively within an international framework
• To develop a deeper level of self-awareness; to be a critical and creative listener, thinker, ‘actor’;
• To be aware of the need for an open mind-set that fosters every challenge as an opportunity (both within personal and career/ business context)
• To initiate (besides collaborating) creative ideas to find solutions, approaches and gradually realizing own responsibility in relation to the self and within the context of a group of individuals

column1: <body>In dit laatste vak van het eerste jaar wordt het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid centraal gesteld. Hoe wordt dit beleid gemaakt, welke veronderstellingen liggen aan het beleid ten grondslag, wat is de rol van de politiek en van criminaliteitscijfers daarbij?  Welk soort maatregelen wordt door de Gemeente getroffen en welke effecten (bedoelde en onbedoelde) hebben deze? Het is de bedoeling dat de student voor het beantwoorden van deze vragen gebruik maakt van de kennis die hij of zij heeft opgedaan bij de eerdere vakken. Daarnaast moet de student zich grondig verdiepen in het beleid. De student stelt zelf een onderzoeksvraag op en beantwoord deze met behulp van desk research. Het vak criminaliteit en samenleving leert de student als het ware om de eigen leefomgeving door een criminologische bril te bekijken</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het succesvol afronden van dit blok kun je:

column2: • Betekenissen van definities van concepten als veiligheid in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid identificeren en evalueren;

• Veronderstellingen, doelstellingen en (beleids)theorieën herkennen in het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid en deze kritisch beoordelen op basis van wetenschappelijke juridische en empirische literatuur;
• Kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve databronnen in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid herkennen en beoordelen;
• Een onderzoeksvraag opstellen gerelateerd aan het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid die te beantwoorden is met bronnenonderzoek (desk research), dit onderzoek uitvoeren en hierover rapporteren;
• Een gestructureerde, samenhangende en kritische analyse schrijven over het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106906,2022,Criminele carrières,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['BJ van Delft, MSc', 'CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. A Bouabid', 'M Moussane, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In dit vak staan daders en hun criminele carrières centraal.  Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om verschillende soorten criminele carrières te beschrijven en te verklaren aan de hand van verschillende criminologische theoretische perspectieven. Daarbij worden de criminele carrières ook bekeken vanuit het perspectief van de daders zelf, en zullen de verschillende relaties tussen werk en criminaliteit worden bestudeerd. In de hoorcolleges wordt dieper ingegaan op de stof, en zullen meerdere gastdocenten verhalen over de loopbanen van criminelen. Ook zal er een college worden gegeven door iemand die vertelt over zijn eigen criminele carrière. Tijdens het practicum zullen de studenten de carrières van echte criminelen bestuderen, en verschillende concepten uit de literatuur daarop leren toepassen</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het volgen van dit blok kun je:

column2: • Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières beschrijven en verklaren.
• Centrale criminologische concepten die samenhangen met het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van criminele carrières benoemen en toepassen op verschillende criminele carrières.
• Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières vergelijken op hun belangrijkste kenmerken, vragen en verklaringen.
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen uitleggen en duiden van verschillende theoretische en methodologische perspectieven op criminele carrières.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Wetenschappelijk onderzoek kan ingezet worden om het veiligheidsbeleid vorm te geven, op effectiviteit te toetsen en om interventies op het gebied van preventie, opsporing, of vervolging gericht in te zetten (risico-analyse). Dit vak geeft inzicht in de onderzoeksvormen die daartoe van belang kunnen zijn en in de mogelijke methodologische problemen en ethische dilemma’s die zich daarbij kunnen voordoen. Daarnaast belicht het vak de wijze waarop keuzes tot stand komen in beleids- en politieke discussies en hoe daarbij wordt omgegaan met de kennis uit wetenschappelijk onderzoek. In de eerste plaats zal worden ingegaan op de verschillende stromingen in het evaluatieonderzoek en de typen onderzoek die binnen de beleidscyclus kunnen worden gedaan. Evaluatieonderzoek is veelal onderzoek in opdracht van beleidsmakers. Daarom wordt er in dit vak in de tweede plaats ingegaan op de – soms complexe – verhouding tussen beleidsmakers en onderzoekers bij opdrachtonderzoek (‘wetenschap op bestelling’), op de benutting van onderzoeksresultaten in het beleid en op de problemen en dilemma’s waarmee onderzoekers in de praktijk te maken kunnen krijgen die de integriteit en onafhankelijkheid van het onderzoek bedreigen. In het tweede deel van dit vak laten we zien hoe kwalitatieve analyse gebruikt kan worden om de aannames die aan beleid ten grondslag liggen bloot te leggen. Voor effectief veiligheidsbeleid is het niet alleen van belang om te weten wat werkt en wat niet, maar ook om effectieve interventies vervolgens gericht (op de juiste personen en situaties) te kunnen inzetten. In het laatste deel van dit vak wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het ontwerpen en toepassen van (risico)taxatiemodellen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Veel criminologen komen terecht in functies waarin zij te maken krijgen met onderzoek dat van belang is voor het ontwikkelen van een effectief veiligheidsbeleid, bijvoorbeeld als gebruiker, uitvoerder of opdrachtgever van dergelijk onderzoek. Het doel van dit vak is tweeledig. In de eerste plaats beoogt dit vak inzicht en vaardigheden te bieden in het type onderzoek dat van belang is voor effectief veiligheidsbeleid en in de mogelijke methodologische problemen en ethische dilemma’s die zich daarbij kunnen voordoen. In de tweede plaats is het doel van dit vak om gevoel te ontwikkelen voor de context waarin dit onderzoek wordt uitgevoerd en al dan niet doorwerkt in beleid. Daarmee draagt dit vak bij aan het kritische gebruik van onderzoek door criminologen die in de beleidspraktijk terechtkomen</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105711,2022,Criminology: a broadening minor. The twilight zone between legal and illegal.,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. JW Hiah', 'jonkvrouw TMA van Suchtelen, MSc', 'LK Krijger', 'RI Timmerman, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Crime might seem like an easy concept to grasp (e.g. murder, theft), but many phenomena are in the twilight zone between the legal and the illegal (e.g. ecological damage). Some harmless acts are criminalized, other acts are ‘awful but lawful’. This broadening minor introduces students to different perspectives on crime, criminalization and victimization. The course offers tools for a critical understanding of a diverse range of crimes, their causes, and their offenders and victims. In addition to understanding crime, the minor explores a variety of approaches to respond to crime, ranging from criminal law to social prevention. Students will be introduced to the core concepts, theories and methods of criminology, to the basics of crime control and prevention and to current issues in the field of crime and justice.

Contemporary developments in criminology, crime and justice run as a thread through this minor. We pay attention to how crime, subversion and approaches to it relate to inequality and sustainability. Given that many developments in contemporary crime are inherently global, we pay attention to the role of globalization, while not losing track of local particularities in crime (policy). Think for instance of topics such as organized drugs trade in the Port of Rotterdam, cybercrime, radicalization and deforestation.

Students will learn about different perspectives on crime, criminalization and victimization. The dominant perspective in this broadening minor is a sociological and critical approach to the study of crime, by paying attention to power dimensions that are inherent to criminalization and by paying attention to unintended social consequences of crime control policies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, you are able to:

column2: • Explain and apply core concepts in criminology
• Describe research methods and data sources in criminology and assess their strengths and weaknesses
• Describe the key criminological theories and assess their strengths and weaknesses.
• Assess the implications of different perspectives on crime for crime prevention and control
• Apply the key criminological theories to specific criminological phenomena and current issues
• Describe and compare different approaches to and strategies of crime control and prevention
• Express and debate one's own understanding of behaviour in the twilight zone between the legal and illegal with one's peers
• Collaborate with one's peers about real-life cases of behaviour in the twilight zone between the legal and the illegal

column1: This course brings together two extensively researched topics that are often treated in isolation: crisis management and responsible leadership. With this goal, we focus on two interrelated issues—(a) the role of leaders in crisis situations, and (b) how leaders confront a crisis of confidence because of increasing scrutiny and pressures to act in responsible ways. The first part of the course looks at how leaders communicate during a crisis. Leader actions in a crisis have a decisive impact on crisis outcomes, whether negative or positive. Moreover, because of their controversial actions, ‘star CEOs’ (e.g., Elon Musk) can create crisis-like situations for themselves and their organizations. The second part examines the pressures that today’s leaders need to navigate, from increased demands for transparency to social purpose and stakeholder criticism. In light of these amplified challenges, we spotlight contemporary developments facing the C-suite including forms of activism (e.g., CEO and employee activism), distributed or remote leadership (especially in light of COVID), and social purpose leadership, and reflect on their risks and benefits.
We will draw on a combination of relevant literature, guest lectures, and business cases to unpack the afore-mentioned topics.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Gain a nuanced perspective on the interlinkages of crisis management and responsible leadership
• Understand the complex landscape in which leadership communication strategies unfold
<li>Work individually and in teams to apply theoretical insights and developments in communication best practices to evaluate contemporary examples and cases

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106360,2022,Critical Heritage Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

In this course students will be introduced to the interdisciplinary field of heritage studies and its critical approaches to cultural heritage, both tangible (e.g. artefacts and monuments) and intangible (e.g. traditions and languages). We will explore the relevant theoretical concepts and approaches to study cultural heritage and look at the complex relationships between cultural heritage and power dynamics, especially those involving identity (belonging), sustainable development, tourism and human rights.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

The purpose of the course is to acquire academic insight into and adopt a critical attitude towards cultural heritage. At the end of the seminar, you will have knowledge of cultural heritage, and, in particular, the politics that are at stake in ‘the making’ of cultural heritage. Students are expected to develop an understanding of the political, economic and social dimension of cultural heritage. Moreover, you are able to reflect on cultural heritage on a theoretical and analytical level. In doing so, you’ll be able to critically reflect on academic literature, relate theory and research to specific case studies and, finally, write a well-informed essay on a relevant sub-theme.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course introduces students to critical theory and aims to equip students with the conceptual tools forged by some of the major scholars working in the critical traditions such as Horkheimer, Adorno and Marcuse (The Frankfurt School), Foucault and Deleuze & Guattari (The Paris School), the Black Panther Party, Angela Davis and the Combahee River Collective (the Black Liberation Movement), and radical thought in Italy (the Autonomist movement).

Students learn to apply critical theory as a “martial art”: a means of self-defence against discursive and non-discursive structures of violence without having the right for unfair attacks (i.e., submission to the rules of responsible speech). The course provides students with the necessary historical and theoretical background needed to understand later developments in the fields of critical theory and cultural analysis (as offered by the various majors in the Humanities) and the skills to become “Critical World Citizens” in the present.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • have basic knowledge of the foundational schools and thinkers of critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the main concepts and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the historical context of the main thinkers and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the various intersections of class, race, gender and nature that undergird the critical theories studied in this course.
• be able to apply critical theory to domains as varied as science, education, culture, media, and sports.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106287,2022,Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['CR Koekoek, MSC MA', 'J van der Klaauw, MA', 'prof.dr. LHJ Noordegraaf - Eelens']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is critical thinking? This question seems more relevant than ever in an era of ‘post-truth politics’ and ‘alternative facts’, where it can be difficult to separate conspiracy from critique. This module explores some of the most important post-war continental social-philosophical theories and their consequences for disciplinary thinking in the humanities and social sciences. Learning about these theories will allow you to better understand and gain new insight into contemporary societal problems. The guiding notion in this course is that of critique, as developed by the Frankfurt School. We investigate the relation between society and the knowledge produced and methods used by social sciences and humanities (but also by medical and environmental sciences). We focus on critical theory (Habermas, Frankfurt School), poststructuralism (Foucault), feminist critique, postcolonial critique, tentacular thinking (Haraway) and critical realism (Latour).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following the course ‘Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities’, students should be able to…

column2: • Interpret the practices of philosophical critique (with regard to the student’s primary scientific discipline)
• Apply the theories discussed in the lectures, tutorials and texts in relation to specific cases (from the student’s primary scientific discipline)
• Reflect critically on the various roles that scientific knowledge plays in society
• Evaluate the different kinds of critique discussed in the course, both historically and systematically
• Assess the societal relevance of philosophical critique (in relation to one’s primary scientific discipline)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109089,2022,Cross-sector Partnerships for Sustainable Development,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['drs. MI de Wal', 'SM Pfisterer, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Many practitioners and academics alike argue that complex societal challenges, including sustainable development, require collaborative processes between different sectors of society (state, market, and civil society). Cross-sector partnerships are therefore also an important part of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) agenda and even have their own goal: the 17th SDG is to ‘strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development’. Despite all the positive rhetoric on cross-sector partnerships, critical voices point to their limited success in addressing the systemic causes underlying the severe sustainability challenges of our times. In this course, participants are therefore encouraged to critically analyze the concept of cross-sector partnerships, their role in sustainable development and their possible impact and frailties. As such, the course builds specifically on the core courses Sustainability Grand Challenges and Global Business Strategies, where collaboration for sustainability is introduced. This course, however, focuses on cross-sector partnerships not necessarily from a business perspective, but rather form a multi-actor perspective.

In the course, participants are stimulated to critically look at the drivers of cross-sector partnerships, explore different types of cross-sector partnerships and the process of navigating these, carefully assess the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development, and view partnerships as new forms of governance and explore issues of legitimacy and democracy. An important element of this course is the link between theoretical concepts and their practical relevance and case studies therefore play an important role. This course is developed and taught by staff of the Partnerships Resource Centre (PrC), a specialist research centre at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. The PrC connects scientifically sound research and practitioner experience of cross-sector partnerships to aid sustainable and inclusive development.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, participants will be able to:

column2: Explain the concept of cross-sector partnerships for sustainable development;
Classify the different drivers and challenges of cross-sector partnerships;
Distinguish between different types of cross-sector partnerships;
Apply theoretical knowledge about partnerships for sustainable development to real-world situations;
Explain the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development;
Analyze cross-sector partnerships from different theoretical perspectives;
Critically reflect on the idea of partnerships for sustainable development.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104981,2022,Crosscultural Psychology - Fundamentals and Ethnic Differences,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MJ Gorgievski', 'prof.dr. MPh Born']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With increasing globalization, we get in touch with different cultures more and more. In a city such as Rotterdam, where people from over 100 countries live and work, knowledge and skills in cross-cultural contacts have become essential. This minor deals with various important themes across psychological subdisciplines, including emotions and psychopathology in different cultures, cultural differences in education and in attachment, working in intercultural teams, well-being of expatriates and immigrants, and problems in conducting cross-cultural research and assessment.

This minor is intended for all students who are interested in intercultural issues and in psychology. The minor aims to increase students’ awareness of cultural differences and contributes to the development of a broader academic attitude. Working during the course with students from diverse cultural backgrounds will deepen students’ knowledge through experiencing different cultural backgrounds and viewpoints themselves.

The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will in principle be English. It will be possible to answer open ended questions on the exam in Dutch.

Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. Students who do not have a background in psychology need to be aware they may need to put in extra effort in order to master the material and understand the underlying psychological principles. Students who do not have a background in problem-based learning (PBL) will need to know the didactical model of PBL will be used in this course. Before the course, a short digital introduction will be provided on PBL for these students, which they will need to have completed.

In this module we will study the main themes within cross-cultural psychology. Classic concepts in this domain will be discussed, as well as the factors that need to be considered when performing and interpreting cross-cultural research. Themes that are subsequently treated are: cultural differences and similarities in cognitions, emotions and autobiographical memory, how normal and abnormal behavior is perceived in different cultures, and cross-cultural issues related to society and work. Examples belonging to this last theme are experiences of expatriates, and preferred leadership styles across cultures.
- Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
- Teaching materials: Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.

In Module 2, students learn about psychological aspects related to living in a multicultural society. This module deals with more fundamental issues, such as stereotyping and prejudice, acculturation strategies and multicultural identity development. In addition, this module addresses issues that professionals may encounter when dealing with people from different cultural backgrounds in practice. Here one can think of topics such as: the role of ethnicity in diagnostics and treatment of psychopathology, immigrants’ study success, the influence of migration on mental health, discrimination at work and team performance.
- Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
- Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.

Modules 1 and 2 will be closed with a separate exam each. The exam consists of true/false statements and (short-answer) open-end questions. In addition, during Module 2 you will work in couples to prepare a presentation. During the last tutorial meeting of module 2, you will give this presentation to the students in your tutorial group.
The final grade will be a weighted average of both Exam Part 1 and Exam Part 2, plus the grade for the presentation (weights 2 + 2 + 1).

In order to pass the course, the minimum weighted average of both Exam Part 1, Exam Part 2 must be a 5.5. Each exam separately (Part 1 and Part 2), needs to be graded with a 5.0 at minimum. That means students can to some extent compensate an insufficient grade for one part of the minor. In addition, the assessment of the final presentation needs to be a 5.5 or higher.
Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students gain insight into the following overarching themes: cross-cultural differences in child development, cognitions, emotions, personality, intelligence, psychopathology and the meaning of working.
• Students gain insight into methodological issues that play a role when conducting cross-cultural research.
• Students gain insight into ethnic differences and similarities in the domains of (mental) health care, education and the labour market.
• Students gain insight into the processes playing a role in stereotyping and discrimination.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The seminars deals with the problems of doing empirical research: how scholars have tested theories, what methods and data sources have been used, how scholars overcame the problems encountered in empirical research, what are the main limitations of their empirical works, and so on. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic and reading material. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature and to summarise it for discussion in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students therefore learn to appreciate standards of research and how to conduct their own research later on.

Topics covered in the course, among others: cultural policies; cultural heritage; cultural demand; artists' labour markets; culture, economy and cities; (temporary) clusters and intermediaries.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of the course is to offer advanced training in the application of cultural economics to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries. The aim is to enable students to select areas of special interest and to become familiar on how empirical research is done by scholars in the field of the cultural and creative industries and to learn to evaluate it.</body>
