column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For better or for worse, economics is a most influential theory of human behavior and a popular tool for rationalizing decisions. Economic perspectives and arguments are important in debates on public policy of almost any kind. Decision-makers in businesses draw heavily on aspects of economic theory. Economic reasoning is also increasingly employed in the cultural sector. In this course, we discuss the theoretical underpinnings of cultural economics, to help students in harnessing economics for their own purposes.

We do so by discussing ‘classic’ theoretical issues and debates that illuminate the foundations of economics. We begin with two fundamental aspects of economics, price theory and welfare economics, as well as their limitations. We continue with four main themes in cultural economics: (1) public goods, (2) intrinsic motivation, (3) uncertainty and taste formation, as well as (4) superstars. We round off the course with a discussion of economic perspectives on entrepreneurship.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course will help you to better understand the foundations of economics in general. You will develop an overview of the main themes in cultural economics. We encourage a critical, but constructive approach to the application of economics for decision-making in the cultural sector. Usually, the question is not whether economics is perfect but whether there is a superior alternative for a specific purpose, for instance to structure your thoughts, to interpret empirical evidence and to prepare your own empirical research or to convince others. All of this will serve you as a solid basis for subsequent courses, and help you define your specific areas of interest in further stages of the M.A. in Cultural Economics & Entrepreneurship.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106380,2022,Cultural Entrepreneurship: Empirical Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EMMP Loots', 'dr. JA Do Carmo Junior', 'L Marques']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The seminar builds on the ‘Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory’ course in Term 1. By means of weekly subjects and a number of assignments (including a mini-research in group), students will become familiar with and evaluate how cultural entrepreneurship scholars research the field. The sessions simultaneously deal with a number of prominent entrepreneurship themes and the various research methods that are being applied to address those research themes. Some examples can include case studies of entrepreneurship and place, policy for entrepreneurship, quantitative testing of entrepreneurial traits and successes, entrepreneurial networks, big data challenges in relation to entrepreneurship, ethnography in entrepreneurship, etc. Guest speakers working within the field are invited, and one of the last sessions entails a study trip (if the C19-situation allows us to do so) during which we apply our insights.

The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the weekly topic and reading materials. Students are expected to read and prepare for discussing the literature in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students get acquainted with the standards of research in entrepreneurship and will be able to practice those standards within individual and group assignments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to get acquainted with empirical research in the setting of Cultural Entrepreneurship. The course can be considered to be an advanced training in the application of entrepreneurship theory to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries, and should allow students to independently and in group develop research on the subject.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106375,2022,Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EMMP Loots', 'LFF de Poorter']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The notion of “entrepreneurship” is commonly associated with the discovery and pursuit of new business opportunities through the creation of firms. The ultimate aim of entrepreneurial activity is seldom profit or personal wealth-creation, but rather realizing new ideas and being free from restraints. Similarly, artistic and creative work is often about the introduction of novelty, and artists and creative professionals seek to create the conditions and to overcome the barriers to be able to develop works of art and creative goods or services.

Different approaches to and theories on entrepreneurship coincide, which we will explore during this course. The series of lectures in term 1 will introduce students to the diverse facets of the entrepreneurship literature, yet, not without making the necessary connections to the practice of entrepreneurship within the cultural and creative industries. We do so by specialist readings, exercises, group work and interventions by guests. The course introduces students to professional research in cultural entrepreneurship and teaches how to critically engage with this literature. Topics of the course include (but are not limited to):

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to offer an advanced training in cultural entrepreneurship by surveying the field of (cultural) entrepreneurship. It provides students with a solid background in the subject as a basis for subsequent courses and it enables them to select areas of special interest to pursue during the MA.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106344,2022,Cultural Heritage Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. SL Reijnders'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The scientific study of cultural heritage has developed significantly in recent decades. Not only has the interest in this subject grown explosively, also what is exactly meant by 'cultural heritage' has been changing rapidly.

Until recently, attention was focused mainly on forms of material culture of seemingly undisputed value, such as museum artifacts, monuments, and archaeological sites. However, the concept of cultural heritage has broadened considerably. It now also includes intangible forms of culture, such as rituals, customs, and traditions, which are usually associated with non-Western cultures and traditional folk culture. At the same time, within the heritage sector there is a noticeable growing interest in the role of (new) media in the creation and (re)presentation of a shared past.

The course Cultural Heritage Studies offers students an introduction to the above developments. Students take note of recent publications in these fields, do their own research - both individually and in groups - and present their findings during class meetings. For students in Arts and Culture Studies, this course provides an introduction to the heritage branch in the program and elucidates the canonization of arts and culture. Students in History and Media & Communication Studies with an interest in the handling of the present with the past will find this course a welcome addition to their usual curriculum.
NB the maximum number of participants in this course is 25.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this course is to gain knowledge and an understanding of cultural heritage, in particular relating to contemporary developments within the field of heritage studies. This insight is obtained by a) critically examining, summarizing and presenting current, scientific literature; b) applying this literature to concrete examples.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106474,2022,Cultural Identities and New Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Paz Alencar'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In recent years, mainly with the advent of digital technology, new media platforms and transnational media networks have become central in the study of cultural identity and acculturation processes. New media is redefining the meaning of cultural identity and shaping the integration experiences of different ethnic migrant groups in both Western and non-Western societies. The purpose of this course is to unravel the intricate relationships between new media, in, and cultural identity and acculturation through the process of definition, interpretation, and critical analysis. In this course, students will develop their own research project to examine the relationships between new technologies and cultural identity from the perspective of migration, focusing on community networks and practices to explain the new dynamics of connection and bond formation among migrants, and the development of transnational socializing in online environments. Building on qualitative interview and content analysis methodologies, students will investigate the various ways in which (ethnic) migrant groups and institutions are appropriating such new technologies and the implications of these practices for their adaptation experiences in their entirety.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Key theoretical perspectives on the study of cultural identities.
• The main theoretical approaches to the analysis of the role of digital media in cultural identity processes.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Critically analyze new media as spaces for communication and network practices adopted by different migrant populations.
• Analyze digital initiatives focusing on migrants’ experiences in relation to identity negotiations and media use.
• Collect and analyze data based on interview research and qualitative content analysis.
• Report and present research findings in a clear, organized style.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106370,2022,Cultural Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. V Morea', 'L Marques']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will cover components of arts and culture management, including strategy, marketing, fundraising and leadership. Besides theoretical approaches to these topics, practical examples and case studies from international practice will be used to make the peculiarities of the management of arts and cultural organisations clear.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Arts and cultural organisations are in important respects different from other organisations. The goal of this course is to introduce the student to the principles of cultural  management. Here the particular and peculiar questions of management of arts and cultural organisations will be explored.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106378,2022,Cultural Organisations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. C Dalla Chiesa'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Organisations are of great importance in the production and realization of cultural value. The first half of this course will analyse the fundamental questions underlying the cultural organisations. We explore economic and alternative explanations for the existence of cultural organisations. We analyze the difference between formal and informal organisations in the cultural sector, and their relative importance. We explore the methodological side of studying organisations. How is this best done? How important are metaphors for the imagination of organization? And how important is the interpretive side of the analysis of organisations. Finally we explore how institutional logics within organisations are the most important source of conflict.

The second half of the course explores particular challenges that cultural organisations face, through the analysis by students of a cultural organisation of their choice. Why do creative firms choose to cluster, or integrate? How to motivate creative workers, and is this different from motivating workers in the commercial sector? What type of conflicts are likely to arise in cultural organisations? How do cultural organisations develop a mission? And how can we evaluate the cultural and social goals of cultural organisations?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You can explain the most common economic theories for the existence of firms.
• You can explain the difference between formal organisations and informal organisations such as innovation commons.
• You can explain some of the important advantages and disadvantages of different methodological approaches to the study of (cultural) organisations.
• You can explain the importance of institutional logics in shaping cultural organisations, and how this is a potential source of intra-firm conflict.
• You are able to explain how we can assess the non-economic goals of an organisation, and how we can evaluate these.
• You are able to use the theoretical insights above to analyse particular organisations and industries within the cultural sector.
• You are able to use this analysis to highlight potential danger and opportunities for a cultural organisation.
• You are able to present your analysis in an academic manner, as well as in a format that would be useful in a cultural organisation.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107116,2022,Cultural Participation and Taste,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. TL Koren', 'OC Kriebl-Bruno']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this research workshop, we will critically assess theoretical and empirical debates on cultural participation and taste and carry out small quantitative and qualitative research projects on the topic. Over the years, Pierre Bourdieu’s classic theory on taste, cultural classification and inequality has been applied to new art forms, expanded upon, and criticized. More generally, a shift has taken place from analyzing what culture audiences consume to how audiences consume culture. Similarly, where Bourdieu’s theory focused on class, recent research has taken a much wider range of social identities (including race, gender, sexuality, disability) into account. In this research workshop we will be exploring Bourdieusian and non-Bourdieusian theories of taste, cultural participation, and identity. We will assess, among other topics, the role of digitization and online consumption, access to cultural facilities, micro-sociologies of culture venues and the relationship between social identities and cultural consumption. To address these topics, students will learn about quantitative and qualitative methods to analyse cultural participation and taste.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between taste, cultural participation, social identities, and inequality. Secondly, students train their quantitative research skills, through a data analysis assignment. Finally, students apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to develop and conduct a small qualitative research project on the topic of cultural participation and taste.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106574,2022,Cultural Sociology,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. J Peters', 'prof.dr. PPL Berkers']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing – yet fuzzily bounded – areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology is witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’ in a broad sense) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas, such as politics, economy, the state, etc. However, as ‘culture’ is difficult, if not impossible, to define, discussions often lack conceptual clarity, leading to truisms like ‘culture matters’.

This course addresses major theories and contemporary debates in cultural sociology. Besides discussing classical sociological traditions (Marx, Durkheim, Weber) and conceptions of culture, we will discern six ideal typical approaches in cultural sociology: (1) culture as an instrument of power (neo-Marxism and conflict sociology), (2) culture as (cognitive) structure (neo-Durkheimian sociology and structuralism), (3) culture as meaningful action (neo-Weberian sociology and rationalization), (4) culture as a product of social interaction (symbolic interactionism and ethnomethodology), (5) cultural as signification (semiotics) and (6) culture as embodied practice (practice and performance theory).

While most contemporary research usually draws on several of these approaches, we aim to provide a degree of intellectual clarity by disaggregating these traditions. Including both classical theories as well as related contemporary empirical studies, this course will stimulate systematic and critical sociological thinking, and provide a necessary compass to navigate current debates in cultural sociology. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Current theoretical insights, academic debates and approaches in the sociological thinking about culture
• Reproduce and contextualize contemporary theories, insights, and academic debates in cultural sociology
• Apply relevant cultural sociological theories and concepts to empirical reality

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106385,2022,Cultural Sociology of Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is founded in a cultural sociological approach to the phenomenon of tourism, focusing on key concepts and theories which are relevant in the study of tourism as embedded in wider socio-cultural context in which they occur and acquire significance. First, the course will address both seminal theories as well as cutting-edge research on the historical development of tourism, paying particular attention to the underlying interests, activities and concerns which are attached to this phenomenon in its respective context. Moving from tourism and travel in pre-modernity, via the massification of tourism during modernity towards the contemporary nichification of tourism in postmodernity, the course will illuminate central issues related to the practice of tourism in relation to the particular ‘Zeitgeist’ in which it occurs. Second, the course will dive into the practices, motivations and experiences of the tourists themselves, scrutinizing the meanings that they attribute to their travels to and interactions with foreign locations and localities. Third, the destinations of tourists and locals will be of focus, particularly related to transformations of place, host-tourist relationships and issues related to sustainability, both in terms of preserving local culture, economy and the environment. Fourth, rising middle-classes in rapidly developing countries are increasingly having an impact on global tourism flows, resulting in a huge influx of tourists from a plethora of socio-cultural backgrounds, bringing in new opportunities, challenges and considerations. Last, the ever-increasing ubiquity of popular and digital media are brought in dialogue with contemporary and future tourism practices.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main aim of this course is to teach students the basics and fundamental knowledge from the field of tourism from a cultural sociological perspective. Through working with a combination of seminal works in this field as well as more state of the art research, students learn to analyze tourism and related practices within the wider socio-cultural and political contexts in which they occur. In doing so, students will be able to reproduce and contextualize important insights, theories and concepts related to a cultural sociological analysis of tourism. In addition, students will be able to critically and systematically analyse complex socio-cultural processes underlying the evolution of tourism in an age characterized by ongoing processes of globalization, mediation and digitization.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106331,2022,Cultural and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. KJ Kolbe'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is oriented towards developing the understanding of the production and consumption of culture in contemporary societies. It will look at practical aspects of the organization and financing of cultural industries and discuss how these affect the type of art that is created and the cultural products that reach the audiences. Students will be introduced to the key sociological and the cultural economics concepts and theories that help to understand the functioning of cultural and creative industries. In order to highlight the relevance of discussed theoretical perspectives, the lectures will bring in empirical examples from the range of cultural industries taking diverse positions in the arts economy and consider both commercial and non-profit organizations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims at providing students with the basic understanding of the functioning of cultural and creative industries. The lectures introduce the sociological and cultural economics perspectives on the functioning of “high arts” (e.g. contemporary visual art and theatre) and “popular” industries (e.g. film and television) and provide conceptual frameworks to better understand recent developments in cultural industries across sectors and cross-nationally. It deals with applying the theoretical knowledge to real empirical cases by discussing the recent issues and developments in specific cultural organizations or creative fields more generally. The knowledge on the functioning of creative industries offers a useful frame of reference for the remainder of the bachelor program.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106551,2022,Culture Online,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['C Hernandez Esponda', 'dr. SMR Driessen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is little dispute that the rise of digital technologies – file-sharing software, Internet, smart phones, etc. – has radically transformed ‘culture’ in the past decades. Whether it is their impact on consumers’ purchasing modes, the influence of (amateur) experts, changing overall power relations online, or companies’ business models in the cultural industries. What the precise consequences of these transformations and developments are, and will be in the long run, is less evident.

This research workshop focuses on the material and symbolic production of Culture (broadly conceptualized as ‘the arts) and (everyday) culture (e.g., ideas, customs, behavior of people) in online contexts. We will, amongst others, explore transformations in how audiences find and consume cultural products; and examine changes in symbolic production of culture associated with new media (including the role of user-generated content). This might help us to better understand how Culture/culture is shaped and discussed in an online context.

Students conduct a small qualitative case study in which they analyze online cultural content (by means of a content analysis). They formulate a research question, seek appropriate literature, and collect and analyze data to answer their research question. All research questions need to have an explanatory and/or comparative element.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• State-of the art theory on the topic of material and symbolic production of culture in online contexts;
• Common research designs and methods to examine this topic.
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical study on the topic of culture online;
• Report on their findings in oral and written form;
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research;
• Constructively work as part of a team.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107418,2022,Culture, New Media and International Business",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. HH Chen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In international business, it is crucial that the use of various media for internal and external corporate communication is aligned to its own cultural context. This course will analyze the cultural dimensions of international business communication, for instance, how various mobile channels are adopted and perceived in distinct cultural contexts, or how social media could be used to create cohesive groups with their own values and culture. An in-depth understanding of the interplay between culture and media can lead to effective practices to achieve communicative goals in cross-cultural contexts, which is vital for the success of multinational companies. Through case studies, this course will discuss cultural issues in cross-cultural marketing, branding, public relations, and organizational communication. Theories and practical implications supported by empirical case studies will also be introduced to students to build their knowledge base that can inform practice.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Academic perspectives on the importance of culture in international business communication.
• Research on the perception and uses of media in different cultural contexts.
• The interplay between culture and media in an international business settings.
• How new media may shape and change social networks and culture.
• Effectively apply various media for international business with cultural sensitivity.
• Strategically use social media to form groups, shape cultures, and maintain social networks that can promote international business.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106477,2022,Current Perspectives on Popular Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. J Muraro - Kim', 'dr. SMR Driessen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What can superhero movies like Black Panther teach us about today’s society? Or series like the Handmaid’s Tale or Black Mirror? What is the cultural value of memes? And who decides what content is (allowed to be) shared via popular platforms like Instagram or Facebook? As a form of entertainment for the masses, popular culture (movies, series, music, social media, games etc.) has always played a key role in society. In this course, we approach popular culture beyond its entertainment function by paying close attention to both its content and its followers, the fans.

Often popular culture illustrates, reflects on, and helps to better understand the world we live in through representing or questioning societal changes that take place. In this seminar, we explore the interplay between popular culture, media entertainment, and fandom. We do so by examining topics ranging from meme culture to race, and gender to transnational pop culture.

Discussing different theories and popular culture topics each week, we address core questions like: Why and what ways do people engage with popular culture? How has and will popular culture help us understand societal changes?
This course should not be taken if you have already followed CM2232.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on current and past perspectives on popular culture and its role in society.
• The relation between popular culture and societal changes.
• ·Critically assess and compare existing theories on popular culture and societal changes.
• ·Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
• ·Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

column1: The course will cover ten separate, but connected, topics in marketing. Each session will be taught by a different faculty (for questions about the overall course structure or other general matters, contact Christophe Lembregts, the course coordinator). The selection of topics is made by the marketing faculty based on their beliefs about what topics are currently the most timely and relevant in academic marketing research. Some sessions will deal with a relatively well-defined and limited range of issues. Others will cover broader ground, providing a primer to entire sub-fields. Most sessions will be directly related to the research conducted by the respective faculty member, so students are taught by world experts in the domain of every session. The combination of sessions should provide a high-level entry point into academic marketing research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main goal of the course is to familiarize students with key areas of marketing research as well as with different methodological approaches that are influential in marketing. Thus, the course will cover a wide variety of topics and perspectives, spanning consumer behavior, marketing strategy, and quantitative marketing topics. The broad set of topics and methods reflects the diversity of marketing research. You are not expected to pursue research in all of these areas in the future. Rather, we would like the course to help you understand the field and form a clearer idea of what area might be most suitable for you.

The course also serves two additional goals: introducing students to RSM marketing faculty and introducing faculty to students. Our hope is that this course will offer a useful platform on which students can build to develop a successful line of research during their time at ERIM, by exposing them early on to the research carried out at the RSM marketing department and by facilitating interactions between students and faculty and thereby increasing the likelihood of collaborations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The emergence of information and data technologies, together with the sophistication of tools in econometrics and machine learning, have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each individual customer. Such campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. At their core, they require strong data analytics tools in order to be able to predict each customer’s behavior and derive optimal marketing interventions.

This elective will provide students with the necessary knowledge and skills to tackle these challenges. The course will focus as much on the managerial questions as well as on the use of methodologies to address these questions. The elective will be articulated around the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV). We will especially focus on customer-centric tactics firms can use to:

column2: • Enhance customer acquisition (e.g. customer referral programs, seeding strategies)
• Boost customer spending (e.g. loyalty schemes, customer engagement)

column1: To address these challenges, we will use state-of-the-art machine learning methods, including boosting, uplift models, decision trees, etc. Finally, we use rely heavily on the notion of A/B testing and randomized control trials in order to optimize personalized interventions of firms.

This course is an elective in the Business Analytics and Management MSc and starts in February. Depending on the evolution of the COVID19 pandemic, the course will be either online, offline or a hybrid version of both.
The course will consist of approximately 6 lectures (3 hours each), 3 R tutorials (2 hours each), and 4 assignments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and explain the importance of customer analytics in today’s business world and compare it with older approaches of managing marketing challenges;
• Possess a good expertise of companies’ best practices in the domain of customer analytics, and think critically about them;•Transform ill-defined problems into relevant research problems;
• Understand, explain and apply the latest research in the area of customer analytics;
• Understand and explain key customer analytics tools companies have at their disposal to develop customer-centric strategies;
• Manipulate and do data analyses based on real-live datasets, using customer analytics tools using the R programming language (via tutorials)and predict key customer behavioral outcomes;
• Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through the creation of (online) presentations and written reports.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The emergence of information and data technologies have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each customer. Customer-centric marketing campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. Moreover, they also require a good monitoring of their impacts on firms’ profits. In other words, a customer-centric campaign requires companies to answer four key questions:

Customer-centric marketing can be applied to any domain of marketing and, so, is an approach that can be broadly adopted by multinationals. In this course, we will focus on the three key marketing tasks, which relate to the stages of a customer lifecycle: customer acquisition, customer development and customer retention.

The course will focus as much on the managerial questions and challenges, as well as on the use of methods to address these questions. This elective will be articulated around the customer lifecycle and rely on the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Possess a good expertise and think critically about companies’ practices in the domain of customer centricity;
• Understand and explain the latest research in the area of customer centricity;
• Understand and explain the general intuition behind the methods companies have at their disposal to develop a customer-centric marketing strategy;
• Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through (online) presentation and (digital) reporting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108852,2022,Customer Experience Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. CJP Lembregts'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How can companies gain and sustain competitive advantage in an increasingly competitive environment? In recent years, companies have realized that a crucial source of competitive advantage lies in the provision of a compelling customer experience. Customer experience is comprised of all cognitive, emotional, physical, sensorial, and social elements that mark the customer’s interactions with companies or other market actors (De Keyser et al. 2015). Due to the rapid rise of digital and mobile devices, customers are increasingly valuing seamless experiences. In response, leading companies have decided to hire so-called “customer experience managers” to improve their customer experiences. This course discusses the general determinants of great customer experiences across all touch points (prior, during and after purchase) and introduces methods to improve customer experiences.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: Understand and explain the importance of customer experience management for business.
Recognize, understand and explain the determinants of great customer experiences.
Analyse companies’ customer experiences and identify strengths and weaknesses.
Understand and apply methods and techniques to improve customer experiences.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109215,2022,Data Engineering & Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. T Kucukyilmaz', 'N Bosch', 'WL Meiring']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course “Data Engineering & Management” will teach students the fundamentals of data collection, management and visualization. Students will become proficient in collecting data from various sources (e.g. web scraping), merging data from different files, and visualizing the information content in dynamic reports. Students will also build upon their SQL knowledge and learn advanced techniques. This course lays the foundation for the subsequent courses in the second block of the Analytic Decision Makers Track.

Today’s data analysts need to access data from a wide range of resources, merge data from various resources, clean, annotate, and analyse them using various methods, and present their findings in a convincing manner. The above Figure represents the steps and their connections in a typical data analytics framework. The course introduces predecessor and successor steps to data analysis, hence laying a foundation to subsequent courses.
The course is structured around a brief introduction to three fundamental steps in this framework:

column2: • Import: First, data needs to be collected. The course introduces how to collect and integrate data from various sources and import them into a framework where we can examine them. In addition, the course will provide a brief introduction to using APIs for collecting data from the Web.
• Manipulate: Cleaning up and organizing data is an indispensable part of any data management framework. The course introduces principles of organizing, tidying up and manipulating data.

column1: Often, data analytics require working with multiple sources of information. Interconnected datasets are usually called relational, because associations between datasets are also important. The course also introduces relational data models, and forming associations between multiple data sources.

column2: • Communicate: Data visualization is a fundamental method for reaching to conclusions and communicating our findings. The course introduces advanced visualization techniques using programming languages.

column1: In addition, the course provides information on Structured Querying Languages (SQL) and their applications, as Database management systems lay the foundation to data management and analytic frameworks.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Discover, collect, organize, store and transform data
• Apply advanced query mechanics to analyze, merge, and manage data
• Understand practical applications of data management frameworks

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106095,2022,Data Management & Ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['C Wan, MA', 'dr. A Priante', 'prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Data is a key business resource. Web stores such as Amazon or Coolblue use customer data to dispatch purchased products and to make recommendations of new products; banking service providers such as ING or HSBC use data for processing cash and ATM transactions and for assessing a client’s credit worthiness; manufacturers such as BMW and Tesla use data to design and produce cars and to propel self-driving cars. Often, this data is spread within the organization through multiple information systems. In order for organizations to operate successfully, they need to be able to share data. Data management is the field dedicated to enabling the sharing of data such that it is available at the right time, place, user and quality. This course introduces data management topics such as database design, data preparation, manipulation, modeling, alongside with discussions on ethical frameworks that should guide the management of data and data privacy issues.

In addition, the course provides an introduction to blockchain, which is a new and atypical way of organizing data. This type of data solution arose in the wake of the global financial crisis of 2007-2009 with the introduction of Bitcoin, the first cryptocurrency. Ever since, there has been an enormous growth in different types of blockchain based business solutions, some of them meaningful, some of them not. We discuss the basic design, logic and economic incentives underlying the blockchain technology, and discuss real-life applications, hypes and scandals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand, describe and discuss data management topics, such as database design, and data preparation, quality, manipulation, modeling and analysis
• Develop a critical understanding and ability to use data management plan frameworks

column1: This course covers key concepts and techniques in statistical modelling and predictive analytics. Data analysis and predictive analytics is the value creation stage of the data value chain. It enables organizations to make better data-driven decisions, improve operations, and reduce costs; and opens the door to new personalized services for customers. Major transformations are taking place in industry as a result of predictive analytics and this course will prepare students to engage competently in such topics in the workplace. This course emphasizes on business relevance - the content will be delivered with case studies and require students to constantly question how data could be used to create value for firms and customers. Apart from the statistical inference approach that students are introduced in the Bachelor 2 Research Methods course, there will also be a dual focus on using models for predictions. Additionally, as students will gain confidence and skills for conducting data analytics independently, there is a strong component of coding, which will be done in R.

The course material will comprise three large topics. The first on Regressions, covers the basics of multiple linear regression as an extension of the concepts learnt in the Bachelor 2 Research Methods course. This will include, but not limited to, model specification, residual analysis, assumptions of regression, dealing with non-linearity and interactions, prediction, and model comparisons. The second topic focuses on models for discrete outcomes. The course will specifically cover logistic regression as an extension from linear regression, via generalized linear models, and classification trees. The final topic focuses on time-based models and will specifically cover time series and panel data.

This course builds upon previous knowledge in linear regressions in the Bachelor 2 Research Methods course. It is a natural progression from the Data Engineering and Management (B3T1101) course, which will provide students with the basic skills to manipulate and visualize data, and to generate basic insights. The content in both of these courses will be very useful for students participating in this course. This course then bridges into prescriptive analytics that is delivered in the Prescriptive Analytics (B3T1104) course. Additionally, skills learnt in this course are likely to be applied in the Bachelor Projects (B3T1103).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Construct an analytics problem from a given business context or problem
• Explain how limitations of the data influence the choice of model
• Program a statistical model for data analysis, including preparing the data and visualizing the results
• Propose different statistical models to solve the analytics problem; and test their effectiveness, calibrate them, and select the best alternative
• Critique on the robustness of the results obtained from the analysis
• Assess the implications of the analysis on the business context or problem

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The advances in information technologies in the past decade have led to unprecedented digitalization. These technologies have also made it easier for digital businesses to collect, store, and use the personal data of consumers. The high value associated with personal data also creates incentives for adversaries to attack management information systems. Therefore, in the surveillance economy that we live in, invasion of privacy and cyberthreats are arguably some of the critical issues faced by digital businesses.

This course draws on several case studies and is designed to introduce fundamental concepts related to data privacy and cybersecurity. Students will be exposed to privacy and security issues associated with new technologies in social media, cloud computing, smart cities and the Internet of things, and artificial intelligence.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the importance of data privacy and cybersecurity for digital businesses
• Understand the trade-offs between privacy and technological convenience
• Identify various types of cybersecurity threats and evaluate strategies to mitigate these threats

column1: This course is an introduction in basic data science skills for psychologists. Students will learn to develop data analysis scripts in the programming language R. This course is also the basis for later courses using R for inferential statistics.

R is a free software environment for statistical computing and data visualization that has become in the last couple of years the de-facto-standard tool for advanced statistics and reproducible research in psychology and social sciences.

column1: This course addresses the broader societal and organizational context in which data scientists operate. The course is structured according to three levels of analysis: Data science in society, Data science in organizations, and Data science as a personal responsibility. Each level is covered in related lectures that draw on academic papers and recent developments in practice. Data science in society addresses topics such as the impact of data science on market competition, potential discrimination, and data protection and privacy. Data science in organizations addresses topics such as the impact of data science on firm business models, new business development, and organizational practices. Data science as a personal responsibility addresses individual decisions and responsibilities regarding data management, ethics, and privacy protection. Besides an exam, students also complete team assignments related to one of the topics from the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will develop a better understanding of the role and impact of data science in society and in organizations.
Students will develop a better understanding of their personal responsibilities regarding data science practices such as data management, ethics, and privacy protection.

Students practice how to analyze real-world societal and organizational debates relevant to data science. They practice how to use existing academic research to develop an informed position in such debates and to provide management advice on a course of action for organizations.
Students practice team report writing and communication skills.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The allure of a ‘data-driven’ future healthcare system continues to seduce many. Driven by technological developments and increasing opportunities for algorithmic analysis of large and varied datasets, the latest years have seen a continuous stream of hypes and ‘buzzwords’ about the potential of data-driven healthcare technologies. These range from notions like ‘Big Data’, predictive medicine and data science to more recent expressions of hope and potential related to Artificial Intelligence and subfields like machine learning. The underlying promise is remarkably similar: healthcare is expected to improve significantly because more data is collected from varied sources and better analytical techniques are available to meaningfully process these data. Consequently, healthcare delivery is argued to become better, in terms of ‘prevention’ (e.g. early detection of disease markers) or ‘personalization’ (care tailored to individual needs).

Not everybody shares these high hopes regarding new data-driven technologies in healthcare. Many scholars in the field of Critical Data Studies have emphasized the dangers of the perceived “radical shift” that these data-driven healthcare technologies bring. Expressed fears in the scientific and media debates take all sorts of shapes. Publications describe how data analytics will reinforce discrimination and enlarge social inequality, how painful and wrong conclusions are drawn from limited healthcare data and how the use of data analytics could challenge the authority of medical professionals and promote defensive decision-making which might harm patients. Simultaneously, the media often fuels these fears by repetitions of all sorts of modern myths and references to stories in which technologies are misused and out-of-control leading to a variety of harmful effects. Stories about how a large supermarket chain knew that a teen girl was pregnant before her father did are frequently repeated and references to dystopian stories are often made (think about the books Brave New World, 1984, movies such as Minority Report and series such as Black Mirror).

From a medical perspective, several scholars versed in Evidence-Based Medicine take issue with radical claims that data-driven technologies promise to sideline many of the established scientific methodologies, while many of the methodological issues are still relevant with big data analyses. The fear is that based on innovative data analytics, we start to see patterns in data where none exist and that limitations and biases in data will be amplified, leading to incomplete or misguided decision-making by medical professionals and healthcare policymakers with possible detrimental consequences.

This course provides students with insights into the potential and the challenges that come with the set of data-driven technologies in healthcare. Students will gain a better understanding of both the practical aspects of these technologies (i.e. a basic understanding of the logic behind data science and machine learning), but also the relevant political and managerial discussions about how to embed such technologies in healthcare contexts. This course therefore builds on a multidisciplinary, socio-technical perspective on data-driven technologies that also takes into consideration their social, legal, and ethical aspects. This broader, multidisciplinary perspective is not only relevant for better understanding the promises and limits of data-driven healthcare technologies, but also brings students as future healthcare managers in a better position to make balanced decisions about what such technologies can and cannot do.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Compare the various definitions and meanings that are given to data-driven technologies from a technical and socio-technical perspective.
• Conduct a critical discourse analysis of popular media representations about data-driven technologies in healthcare.
• Evaluate under which conditions data-driven technologies can improve healthcare practice.
• Assess the various ethical dimensions of data-driven technologies with the help of different ethical theories.
• Reflect on the possibilities and limitations of algorithmic thinking for decision-making in healthcare organizations.
• Describe the most common regulatory and governance challenges in relation to the embedding of data-driven technologies in various European healthcare systems.

• Produce a strategic advice based on regulatory challenges, social and cultural dimensions and policy strategies for organizations seeking to invest in data-driven technologies in a European Country.”
